['由於時間軸的時間長短不同(如公元前2500年和1949年10月1日），影響了佈局，請修正：struct TimelineEntryView: View {
    let entry: EncyclopediaEntry

    var body: some View {
        HStack(alignment: .top) {
            VStack {
                Text(formattedDate(for: entry.date))
                    .font(.subheadline)
                    .foregroundColor(.gray)
                    .padding(8)
                    .background(Color(UIColor.systemGray6))
                    .cornerRadius(8)
                Circle()
                    .fill(Color.blue)
                    .frame(width: 12, height: 12)
            }
            .padding(.trailing, 12)

            VStack(alignment: .leading, spacing: 12) {
                Text(entry.title)
                    .font(.headline)
                    .foregroundColor(.primary)
                    .padding(.bottom, 2)

                Text(entry.description)
                    .font(.body)
                    .foregroundColor(.primary)
                    .fixedSize(horizontal: false, vertical: true) // 允许内容自适应高度

                if let image = entry.image {
                    Image(image)
                        .resizable()
                        .scaledToFit()
                        .cornerRadius(8)
                        .frame(height: 120)
                        .shadow(radius: 5)
                        .padding(.top, 4)
                
                if let location = entry.location {
                    Text(location)
                        .font(.subheadline)
                        .foregroundColor(.white)
                        .padding(8)
                        .background(Color.purple)
                        .cornerRadius(8)
                        .padding(.bottom, 4)
                }

                }
            }
            .padding(12)
            .background(Color(UIColor.secondarySystemBackground))
            .cornerRadius(12)
            .shadow(radius: 5)
        }
        .padding(.horizontal)
        .padding(.vertical, 8)
    }
}


// 自定义格式化器，支持公元前（BC）、公元后（AD）及完整日期
func formattedDate(for dateRepresentation: DateRepresentation) -> String {
    let dateFormatter = DateFormatter()
    dateFormatter.locale = Locale(identifier: "zh_CN") // 设置中文区域
    dateFormatter.dateFormat = "yyyy年M月d日" // 设置中文日期格式

    switch dateRepresentation {
    case .yearOnly(let year):
        if year < 0 {
            return "公元前\(-year)年"
        } else {
            return "\(year)年"
        }
    case .fullDate(let date):
        return dateFormatter.string(from: date)
    }

using UnityEngine;
using UnityEditor;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;
using System.IO;
using System.Threading.Tasks;

public static class SelectionOperations
{
    #region 常量和變數

    private static readonly string GlobalSelectionsFilePath = "Assets/Editor/GlobalSelections.json";
    private static SelectionGroupsScriptable cachedScriptable;

    #endregion

    #region 菜單項

    [MenuItem("Tools/保存選擇組 %g")] // Ctrl+G as a shortcut
    public static async void SaveCurrentSelectionGroupMenu()
    {
        await EnsureSelectionsLoadedAsync();
        SaveCurrentSelection(saveAsGroup: true);
    }

    [MenuItem("Tools/單獨保存選擇 &s")] // Alt+S as a shortcut
    public static async void SaveCurrentSelectionIndividuallyMenu()
    {
        await EnsureSelectionsLoadedAsync();
        SaveCurrentSelection(saveAsGroup: false);
    }

    #endregion

    #region 方法

    private static async Task EnsureSelectionsLoadedAsync()
    {
        if (cachedScriptable == null)
        {
            cachedScriptable = ScriptableObject.CreateInstance<SelectionGroupsScriptable>();
            await LoadSelectionsAsync(GlobalSelectionsFilePath);
        }
    }

    public static void SaveCurrentSelection(bool saveAsGroup = true)
    {
        if (cachedScriptable == null || cachedScriptable.selectionGroups == null)
        {
            cachedScriptable = ScriptableObject.CreateInstance<SelectionGroupsScriptable>();
            cachedScriptable.selectionGroups = new SelectionGroups();
        }
        else
        {
            // 重新加載最新的選擇組數據
            LoadSelections(ref cachedScriptable.selectionGroups);
        }

        SaveCurrentSelectionInternal(cachedScriptable.selectionGroups, saveAsGroup);
        SaveSelections(cachedScriptable.selectionGroups);
    }

    private static void SaveCurrentSelectionInternal(SelectionGroups selectionGroups, bool saveAsGroup)
    {
        var selectedObjects = Selection.gameObjects.ToList();
        var selectedObjectIDs = selectedObjects.Select(obj => obj.GetInstanceID()).ToList();
        var selectedObjectPaths = selectedObjects.Select(obj => GetGameObjectPath(obj)).ToList();
        var selectedObjectNames = selectedObjects.Select(obj => obj.name).ToList();

        if (saveAsGroup)
        {
            // 生成用于查找现有选择的名称
            string selectionName = GetSelectionName(selectedObjects);

            // 查找是否已经存在相同名称、ID 和路径的选择
            var existingSelection = selectionGroups.selections
                .FirstOrDefault(s => s.name == selectionName &&
                                     s.objectInstanceIDs.SequenceEqual(selectedObjectIDs) &&
                                     s.objectPaths.SequenceEqual(selectedObjectPaths));

            if (existingSelection != null)
            {
                // 如果存在，则更新现有选择的对象
                existingSelection.objectInstanceIDs = selectedObjectIDs;
                existingSelection.objectPaths = selectedObjectPaths;
                existingSelection.objectNames = selectedObjectNames;
            }
            else
            {
                // 如果不存在，则创建新的选择
                var savedSelection = new SavedSelection(selectionName, selectedObjects);
                savedSelection.objectInstanceIDs = selectedObjectIDs;
                savedSelection.objectPaths = selectedObjectPaths;
                savedSelection.objectNames = selectedObjectNames;
                selectionGroups.selections.Add(savedSelection);
            }
        }
        else
        {
            // 单独保存
            foreach (var obj in selectedObjects)
            {
                string selectionName = obj.name;

                // 檢查是否為Prefab
                if (PrefabUtility.IsPartOfPrefabAsset(obj) || PrefabUtility.IsPartOfPrefabInstance(obj))
                {
                    selectionName = "Prefab-" + selectionName;
                }

                // 查找是否已经存在相同名称、ID 和路径的选择
                var existingSelection = selectionGroups.selections
                    .FirstOrDefault(s => s.name == selectionName &&
                                         s.objectInstanceIDs.Contains(obj.GetInstanceID()) &&
                                         s.objectPaths.Contains(GetGameObjectPath(obj)));

                if (existingSelection != null)
                {
                    // 如果存在且 ID 和路径都已经存在，则跳过，不重复保存
                    continue;
                }
                else
                {
                    // 如果不存在，则创建新的选择
                    var savedSelection = new SavedSelection(selectionName, new List<GameObject> { obj });
                    savedSelection.objectInstanceIDs = new List<int> { obj.GetInstanceID() };
                    savedSelection.objectPaths = new List<string> { GetGameObjectPath(obj) };
                    savedSelection.objectNames = new List<string> { obj.name };
                    selectionGroups.selections.Add(savedSelection);
                }
            }
        }
    }


    public static async Task LoadSelectionsAsync()
    {
        await LoadSelectionsAsync(GlobalSelectionsFilePath);
    }

    public static void SaveCurrentSelection(SelectionGroupsScriptable scriptable, bool saveAsGroup = true)
    {
        if (saveAsGroup)
        {
            SaveCurrentSelectionInternal(scriptable.selectionGroups, true);
        }
        else
        {
            // 單獨保存每個選擇的對象
            foreach (GameObject obj in Selection.gameObjects)
            {
                SavedSelection newSelection = new SavedSelection(obj.name, new List<GameObject> { obj });
                scriptable.selectionGroups.selections.Add(newSelection);
            }
        }
        EditorUtility.SetDirty(scriptable);
        // 更新 GlobalSelections.json 文件
        SaveSelections(scriptable.selectionGroups);
    }

    public static void SaveSelections(SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        var jsonData = JsonUtility.ToJson(selectionGroups, true);
        File.WriteAllText(GlobalSelectionsFilePath, jsonData);
        Debug.Log($"Selections saved to {GlobalSelectionsFilePath}");

        // 如果编辑器窗口已经打开，刷新它们
        var windows = Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeAll<SelectionGroupsManager>();
        foreach (var window in windows)
        {
            window.RefreshDataAndGUI();
        }
    }

    public static void LoadSelections(ref SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        if (File.Exists(GlobalSelectionsFilePath))
        {
            string jsonData = File.ReadAllText(GlobalSelectionsFilePath);
            selectionGroups = JsonUtility.FromJson<SelectionGroups>(jsonData) ?? new SelectionGroups();

            // Ensure loaded selection object IDs are valid
            foreach (SavedSelection selection in selectionGroups.selections)
            {
                for (int i = 0; i < selection.objectInstanceIDs.Count; i++)
                {
                    int instanceID = selection.objectInstanceIDs[i];
                    GameObject obj = EditorUtility.InstanceIDToObject(instanceID) as GameObject;
                    if (obj != null)
                    {
                        // Update the object path and name if it has changed
                        selection.objectPaths[i] = GetGameObjectPath(obj);
                        selection.objectNames[i] = obj.name;
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        else
        {
            selectionGroups = new SelectionGroups();
        }
    }

    // 使用JsonUtility進行序列化和反序列化
    public static async Task SaveSelectionsAsync(SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        // 异步保存数据的代码...

        // 在主线程中执行 UI 操作
        EditorApplication.delayCall += () =>
        {
            var windows = Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeAll<SelectionGroupsManager>();
            foreach (var window in windows)
            {
                window.RefreshDataAndGUI();
            }
        };
    }

    public static async Task LoadSelectionsAsync(string filePath)
    {
        if (File.Exists(filePath))
        {
            var jsonData = await File.ReadAllTextAsync(filePath);
            cachedScriptable.selectionGroups = JsonUtility.FromJson<SelectionGroups>(jsonData) ?? new SelectionGroups();
        }
        else
        {
            cachedScriptable.selectionGroups = new SelectionGroups();
        }
    }

    public static void SelectObjectsFromSelection(SavedSelection selection)
    {
        var selectedObjects = new List<GameObject>();

        // 1. 優先使用 objectInstanceIDs 查找物件
        for (int i = 0; i < selection.objectPaths.Count; i++)
        {
            GameObject obj = null;

            // 1.1 使用 objectInstanceIDs 查找
            if (selection.objectInstanceIDs != null && i < selection.objectInstanceIDs.Count && selection.objectInstanceIDs[i] != 0)
            {
                obj = EditorUtility.InstanceIDToObject(selection.objectInstanceIDs[i]) as GameObject;
                Debug.Log(obj != null ? $"Found by Instance ID: {obj.name}" : "Not found by Instance ID");
            }

            // 2. 如果 Instance ID 找不到物件，使用 objectPaths 查找
            if (obj == null && selection.objectPaths != null && i < selection.objectPaths.Count && !string.IsNullOrEmpty(selection.objectPaths[i]))
            {
                obj = FindGameObjectByPath(selection.objectPaths[i]);
                Debug.Log(obj != null ? $"Found by Path: {obj.name}" : "Not found by Path");
            }

            // 3. 如果路徑也找不到，則使用 objectNames 查找
            if (obj == null && selection.objectNames != null && i < selection.objectNames.Count && !string.IsNullOrEmpty(selection.objectNames[i]))
            {
                obj = FindGameObjectByName(selection.objectNames[i]);
                Debug.Log(obj != null ? $"Found by Name: {obj.name}" : "Not found by Name");
            }

            // 如果找到物件，將其添加到 selectedObjects 列表中
            if (obj != null)
            {
                selectedObjects.Add(obj);
            }
        }

        // 如果找到的物件不為空，則選中並聚焦
        if (selectedObjects.Any())
        {
            Selection.objects = selectedObjects.ToArray();
            FocusHierarchyWindow();
        }
        else
        {
            Debug.Log($"No valid objects found in the selection: {string.Join(", ", selection.objectNames)}");
        }
    }

    private static GameObject FindGameObjectByPath(string path)
    {
        var objects = GameObject.FindObjectsOfType<GameObject>(true); // 仅查找当前场景中的对象
        return objects.FirstOrDefault(go => GetGameObjectPath(go) == path);
    }

    private static GameObject FindGameObjectByName(string name)
    {
        var objects = GameObject.FindObjectsOfType<GameObject>(true); // true 代表查找不活躍的物件
        return objects.FirstOrDefault(go => go.name == name);
    }

    public static string GetGameObjectPath(GameObject obj)
    {
        var path = obj.name;
        while (obj.transform.parent != null)
        {
            obj = obj.transform.parent.gameObject;
            path = obj.name + "/" + path;
        }
        return path;
    }

    public static void FocusHierarchyWindow()
    {
        var editorWindowType = typeof(EditorWindow).Assembly.GetType("UnityEditor.SceneHierarchyWindow");
        var hierarchyWindows = Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeAll(editorWindowType);

        if (hierarchyWindows.Length > 0)
        {
            ((EditorWindow)hierarchyWindows[0]).Focus();
        }
        else
        {
            Debug.LogError("No SceneHierarchyWindow found.");
        }
    }

    private static string GetSelectionName(List<GameObject> selectedObjects)
    {
        if (selectedObjects.Count > 1)
        {
            var firstSelectedObject = selectedObjects[0];
            foreach (var selectedObject in selectedObjects)
            {
                if (IsParentOf(firstSelectedObject, selectedObject))
                {
                    return "Multi-" + firstSelectedObject.name;
                }
                else if (IsParentOf(selectedObject, firstSelectedObject))
                {
                    return "Multi-" + selectedObject.name;
                }
            }
        }
        else if (selectedObjects.Count == 1)
        {
            return selectedObjects[0].name;
        }

        return "新群組";
    }

    private static bool IsParentOf(GameObject parent, GameObject child)
    {
        while (child.transform.parent != null)
        {
            if (child.transform.parent.gameObject == parent)
            {
                return true;
            }
            child = child.transform.parent.gameObject;
        }
        return false;
    }

    #endregion

using UnityEditor;
using System.Collections.Generic;
using System.Linq;
using System.IO;
using System.Threading.Tasks;

public static class SelectionOperations
{
    private static readonly string GlobalSelectionsFilePath = "Assets/Editor/GlobalSelections.json";

    public static void SaveCurrentSelection(ref SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        string selectionName = "New Selection";

        if (Selection.gameObjects.Length > 1)
        {
            GameObject firstSelectedObject = Selection.gameObjects[0];
            foreach (GameObject selectedObject in Selection.gameObjects)
            {
                if (IsParentOf(firstSelectedObject, selectedObject))
                {
                    selectionName = "Multi-" + firstSelectedObject.name;
                    break;
                }
                else if (IsParentOf(selectedObject, firstSelectedObject))
                {
                    selectionName = "Multi-" + selectedObject.name;
                    firstSelectedObject = selectedObject;
                }
            }
        }
        else if (Selection.gameObjects.Length == 1)
        {
            selectionName = Selection.gameObjects[0].name;
        }

        List<GameObject> selectedObjects = Selection.gameObjects.ToList();
        selectionGroups.selections.Add(new SavedSelection(selectionName, selectedObjects));
        SaveSelections(selectionGroups);
    }

    private static bool IsParentOf(GameObject parent, GameObject child)
    {
        while (child.transform.parent != null)
        {
            if (child.transform.parent.gameObject == parent)
            {
                return true;
            }
            child = child.transform.parent.gameObject;
        }
        return false;
    }

    public static void SaveSelections(SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        string jsonData = JsonUtility.ToJson(selectionGroups, true);
        Task.Run(() =>
        {
            File.WriteAllText(GlobalSelectionsFilePath, jsonData);
            AssetDatabase.Refresh();
        });
    }

    public static void LoadSelections(ref SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        if (File.Exists(GlobalSelectionsFilePath))
        {
            string jsonData = File.ReadAllText(GlobalSelectionsFilePath);
            selectionGroups = JsonUtility.FromJson<SelectionGroups>(jsonData) ?? new SelectionGroups();

            // Ensure loaded selection object IDs are valid
            foreach (SavedSelection selection in selectionGroups.selections)
            {
                foreach (int instanceID in selection.objectInstanceIDs)
                {
                    GameObject obj = EditorUtility.InstanceIDToObject(instanceID) as GameObject;
                    if (obj != null)
                    {
                        // Update the object path if it has changed
                        selection.objectPaths[selection.objectInstanceIDs.IndexOf(instanceID)] = SelectionOperations.GetGameObjectPath(obj);
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        else
        {
            selectionGroups = new SelectionGroups();
        }
    }

    // 使用JsonUtility進行序列化和反序列化
    public static async Task SaveSelectionsAsync(SelectionGroups selectionGroups)
    {
        string jsonData = JsonUtility.ToJson(selectionGroups, true);
        await File.WriteAllTextAsync(GlobalSelectionsFilePath, jsonData);
    }

    public static async Task<SelectionGroups> LoadSelectionsAsync(string filePath)
    {
        string jsonData = await File.ReadAllTextAsync(filePath);
        return JsonUtility.FromJson<SelectionGroups>(jsonData);
    }

    public static void SelectObjectsFromSelection(SavedSelection selection)
    {
        List<GameObject> selectedObjects = new List<GameObject>();

        foreach (string objectPath in selection.objectPaths)
        {
            GameObject[] objects = Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeAll<GameObject>();
            foreach (GameObject go in objects)
            {
                if (GetGameObjectPath(go) == objectPath)
                {
                    selectedObjects.Add(go);
                    break;
                }
            }
        }

        if (selectedObjects.Count > 0)
        {
            Selection.objects = selectedObjects.ToArray();
            FocusHierarchyWindow();
        }
        else
        {
            Debug.LogWarning("No valid objects found in the selection.");
        }
    }

    public static void FocusHierarchyWindow()
    {
        var editorWindowType = typeof(EditorWindow).Assembly.GetType("UnityEditor.SceneHierarchyWindow");
        var hierarchyWindows = Resources.FindObjectsOfTypeAll(editorWindowType);

        if (hierarchyWindows.Length > 0)
        {
            EditorWindow hierarchyWindow = (EditorWindow)hierarchyWindows[0];
            hierarchyWindow.Focus();
        }
        else
        {
            Debug.LogError("No SceneHierarchyWindow found.");
        }
    }

    public static string GetGameObjectPath(GameObject obj)
    {
        string path = obj.name;
        while (obj.transform.parent != null)
        {
            obj = obj.transform.parent.gameObject;
            path = obj.name + "/" + path;
        }
        return path;
    }
}

        {

                return;

            var selection = filteredSelections[index];

                return;

                newName = EditorGUI.TextField(rect, newName);

                    if (originalIndex != -1)
                    {
                        selectionGroupsScriptable.selectionGroups.selections[originalIndex].name = newName;
                        EditorUtility.SetDirty(selectionGroupsScriptable);
                        SelectionOperations.SaveSelections(selectionGroupsScriptable.selectionGroups);
                    }
                }

                    isRenaming = false;
                    isFilteringEnabled = true; // 重命名結束後啟用篩選
                    endRenamingMode = true;
                    Event.current.Use();
                    GUI.FocusControl(null);
                    UpdateFilteredSelections(); // 更新篩選結果

                else if (Event.current.type == EventType.MouseDown && !rect.Contains(Event.current.mousePosition))
                {
                    isRenaming = false;
                    isFilteringEnabled = true; // 重命名結束後啟用篩選
                    GUI.FocusControl(null);
                    UpdateFilteredSelections(); // 更新篩選結果

                    reorderableList.index = -1; // 重置選中索引

                        Text("Name")

                            .textFieldStyle(RoundedBorderTextFieldStyle())

                            .textFieldStyle(RoundedBorderTextFieldStyle())

                        Text("Email")

                            .textFieldStyle(RoundedBorderTextFieldStyle())

                        Text("Mobile Number")
                        TextField("Enter mobile number", text: $mobileNumber)
                            .textFieldStyle(RoundedBorderTextFieldStyle())

                        Text("Class")
                        TextField("Enter class", text: $studentClass)
                            .textFieldStyle(RoundedBorderTextFieldStyle())

                        Text("Gender")
                        TextField("Enter gender", text: $gender)
                            .textFieldStyle(RoundedBorderTextFieldStyle())
                    }
                }
                .padding()
                
                Spacer()
                
                Button(action: {
                    // Perform save action here
                    isShowingForm = false
                }) {
                    Text("Done")
                        .frame(maxWidth: .infinity)
                        .padding()
                        .background(Color.blue)
                        .foregroundColor(.white)
                        .cornerRadius(10)
                }
                .padding()
            }
            .navigationBarTitle("Add Student", displayMode: .inline)
        }
    }
}

# [Anyone can Access Deleted and Private Repository Data on GitHub ◆ Truffle Security Co.](https://trufflesecurity.com/blog/anyone-can-access-deleted-and-private-repo-data-github)

You can access data from  _deleted forks_,  _deleted repositories_  and even  _private repositories_  on GitHub. And it is available forever. This is known by GitHub, and intentionally designed that way.

This is such an enormous attack vector for all organizations that use GitHub that we’re introducing a new term:  **Cross Fork Object Reference (CFOR)**. A CFOR vulnerability occurs when one repository fork can access sensitive data from another fork (including data from private and deleted forks). Similar to an Insecure Direct Object Reference, in CFOR users supply commit hashes to directly access commit data that otherwise would not be visible to them.

Let’s see a few examples.

## Accessing Deleted Fork Data

Consider this common workflow on GitHub:

1.  You fork a public repository
    
2.  You commit code to your fork
    
3.  You delete your fork
    

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/msknWhH1EkTt7PchLIRCt3npCI.png)

Is the code you committed to the fork still accessible? It shouldn’t be, right? You deleted it.

It is. And it’s accessible forever. Out of your control.

In the video below, you’ll see us fork a repository, commit data to it, delete the fork, and then access the “deleted” commit data via the original repository.

  

  

**You might think you’re protected by needing to know the commit hash. You’re not. The hash is discoverable. More on that later.**

#### How often can we find data from deleted forks?

Pretty often. We surveyed a few (literally 3) commonly-forked public repositories from a large AI company and easily found 40 valid API keys from deleted forks. The user pattern seemed to be this:

1.  Fork the repo.
    
2.  Hard-code an API key into an example file.
    
3.  <Do Work>
    
4.  Delete the fork.
    
      
    

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/CIeHAgW971XDzRy61aiZjY8fBqE.png)

  

**But this gets worse, it works in reverse too:**

## Accessing Deleted Repo Data

Consider this scenario:

1.  You have a public repo on GitHub.
    
2.  A user forks your repo.
    
3.  You commit data after they fork it (and they never sync their fork with your updates).
    
4.  You delete the entire repo.
    
      
    

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/A7rA45DJNYSMUEPCF6tj4wilVC0.png)

Is the code you committed after they forked your repo still accessible?

Yep.

GitHub stores repositories and forks in a  [repository network](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/about-permissions-and-visibility-of-forks#about-visibility-of-forks), with the original “upstream” repository acting as the root node.  [When a public “upstream” repository that has been forked is “deleted”, GitHub reassigns the root node role to one of the downstream forks](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/what-happens-to-forks-when-a-repository-is-deleted-or-changes-visibility#deleting-a-public-repository). However, all of the commits from the “upstream” repository still exist and are accessible via any fork.

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/jCEeyZLP33ugahiS5Oc3N9ms.png)

  

In the video below, we create a repo, fork it and then show how data not synced with the fork can still be accessed by the fork after the original repo is deleted.

  

  

This isn’t just some weird edge case scenario. This unfolded last week:

_I submitted a P1 vulnerability to a major tech company showing they accidentally committed a private key for an employee’s GitHub account that had significant access to their entire GitHub organization. They immediately deleted the repository, but since it had been forked, I could still access the commit containing the sensitive data via a fork, despite the fork never syncing with the original “upstream” repository._

The implication here is that any code committed to a public repository may be accessible  _forever_  as long as there is at least one fork of that repository.

**It gets worse.**

## Accessing Private Repo Data

Consider this common workflow for open-sourcing a new tool on GitHub:

1.  You create a private repo that will eventually be made public.
    
2.  You create a private, internal version of that repo (via forking) and commit additional code for features that you’re not going to make public.
    
3.  You make your “upstream” repository public and keep your fork private.
    

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/xImmfuPpiSy9ttCvAMC5G46bGSk.png)

Are your private features and related code (from step 2) viewable by the public?

Yes. Any code committed between the time you created an internal fork of your tool and when you open-sourced the tool, those commits are accessible on the public repository.

Any commits made to your private fork  _after_  you make the “upstream” repository public are not viewable. That’s because changing the visibility of a private “upstream” repository results in two repository networks - one for the private version, and one for the public version.

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/zOeORJBOu7eK4cx0y2qdgtXNW4.png)

In the video below, we demonstrate how organizations open-source new tools while maintaining private internal forks, and then show how someone could access commit data from the private internal version via the public one.

  

  

Unfortunately, this workflow is one of the most common approaches users and organizations take to developing open-source software. As a result, it’s possible that confidential data and secrets are inadvertently being exposed on an organization's public GitHub repositories.

  

## How do you actually access the data?

By directly accessing the commit.

Destructive actions in GitHub’s repository network (like the 3 scenarios mentioned above) remove references to commit data from the standard GitHub UI and normal git operations. However, this data still exists and is accessible (if you know the commit hash). This is the tie-in between CFOR and IDOR vulnerabilities - if you know the commit hash you can directly access data that is not intended for you.

Commit hashes are SHA-1 values.

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/EoVCvCLjHvZJCuMrrZ0ZwQd3W8M.png)

  

If a user knows the SHA-1 commit hash of a particular commit they want to see, they can directly navigate to that commit at the endpoint: https://github.com`/<user/org>/<repo>/commit/<commit_hash>`. They’ll see a yellow banner explaining that “[t]his commit does not belong to any branch of this repository, and may belong to a fork outside of the repository.”

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/B0wRJU4mjHvmKdy7mpZ3Z3wRV8.png)

  

**Where do you get these hash values?**

Commit hashes can be brute forced through GitHub’s UI, particularly because the git protocol permits the use of  [short SHA-1 values](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Revision-Selection#:~:text=to%20any%20commit.-,Short%20SHA%2D1,-Git%20is%20smart)  when referencing a commit. A short SHA-1 value is the minimum number of characters required to avoid a collision with another commit hash, with an absolute minimum of 4. The keyspace of all 4 character SHA-1 values is 65,536 (16^4). Brute forcing all possible values can be achieved relatively easily.

For example, consider this commit in TruffleHog’s repository:

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/yPbRdgv9LoasW1BXLK09dZNMSXs.png)

  

To access this commit, users typically visit the URL containing the full SHA-1 commit hash:  [https://github.com/trufflesecurity/trufflehog/commit/07f01e8337c1073d2c45bb12d688170fcd44c637](https://github.com/trufflesecurity/trufflehog/commit/07f01e8337c1073d2c45bb12d688170fcd44c637)

But users don’t need to know the entire 32 character SHA-1 value, they only need to correctly guess the Short SHA-1 value, which in this case is  `07f01e`.

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/jji5JQSyL5Bh0OJtpMQDB65DE.png)

[https://github.com/trufflesecurity/trufflehog/commit/07f01e](https://github.com/trufflesecurity/trufflehog/commit/07f01e)

But what’s more interesting; GitHub exposes a public events API endpoint. You can also query for commit hashes in the  [events archive](https://www.gharchive.org/)  which is managed by a 3rd party, and saves all GitHub events for the past decade outside of GitHub, even after the repos get deleted.

## GitHub’s Policies

We recently submitted our findings to GitHub via their VDP program. This was their response:

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/G9xGKRx7gPHauxianQClKVxPE.png)

  

After reviewing the documentation, it’s clear as day that GitHub designed repositories to work like this.

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/eE6IuZrodHY2R0pBWcGHKPNxI.png)

  

![](https://framerusercontent.com/images/UpywoiGAzxzDtqcMAzLxKeW6dwQ.png)

[https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/what-happens-to-forks-when-a-repository-is-deleted-or-changes-visibility](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/working-with-forks/what-happens-to-forks-when-a-repository-is-deleted-or-changes-visibility)

We appreciate that GitHub is transparent about their architecture and has taken the time to clearly document what users should expect to happen in the instances documented above.

Our issue is this:

The average user views the separation of private and public repositories as a security boundary, and understandably believes that any data located in a private repository cannot be accessed by public users. Unfortunately, as we documented above, that is not always true. Whatsmore, the act of deletion implies the destruction of data. As we saw above, deleting a repository or fork does not mean your commit data is actually deleted.

## Implications

We have a few takeaways from this:

1.  **As long as one fork exists, any commit to that repository network (ie: commits on the “upstream” repo or “downstream” forks) will exist forever.**
    
    1.  This further cements our view that the only way to securely remediate a leaked key on a public GitHub repository is through key rotation. We’ve spent a lot of time documenting how to rotate keys for the most popularly leaked secret types - check our work out here:  [howtorotate.com](https://howtorotate.com/docs/introduction/getting-started/).
        

2.  GitHub’s repository architecture necessitates these design flaws and unfortunately, the vast  **majority of GitHub users will never understand how a repository network actually works and will be less secure** because of it.
    

3.  As secret scanning evolves, and we can hopefully scan all commits in a repository network,  **we’ll be alerting on secrets that might not be our own**  (ie: they might belong to someone who forked a repository). This will require more diligent triaging.
    
      
    
4.  While these three scenarios are shocking, that doesn’t even cover all of the ways GitHub could be storing deleted data from your repositories. Check out our  [recent post](https://trufflesecurity.com/blog/trufflehog-scans-deleted-git-branches)  (and related TruffleHog update) about how you also need to scan for secrets in deleted branches.
    

Finally, while our research focused on GitHub, it’s important to note that some of these issues exist on other version control system products.

// Tính toán thân nến và bóng nến
body = math.abs(close - open)
upperTail = open > close ? (high - open) : (high - close)
lowerTail = open > close ? (close - low) : (open - low)

// Xác định nến Pinbar
isBullishPinbar = lowerTail >= 1.5 * body and upperTail < 0.2 * body
isBearishPinbar = upperTail >= 1.5 * body and lowerTail < 0.2 * body

// Điều kiện xác nhận với SMA
if confirmBullishWithSMA
    isBullishPinbar := isBullishPinbar and close < movingAverage
    
if confirmBearishWithSMA
    isBearishPinbar := isBearishPinbar and close > movingAverage

// Áp dụng bộ lọc và vẽ biểu đồ
plotshape(isBullishPinbar, style=shape.triangleup, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green)
plotshape(isBearishPinbar, style=shape.triangledown, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red)

// Vẽ đường SMA
plot(movingAverage, color=color.blue, title="SMA", linewidth=2)

confirmBullishWithSMA = input(true, title="Confirm Bullish Pinbar with SMA")

smooth_k = input.int(3, minval=1, title="Smooth K")
smooth_d = input.int(3, minval=1, title="Smooth D")
useStochRSI_filter = input(false, title="Use Stoch RSI Filter")

movingAverage = ta.sma(close, sma_len)
rsi = ta.rsi(close, rsi_len)

// Tính toán Stoch RSI
stochRSI = ta.stoch(rsi, rsi, rsi, stochRSI_len)
smooth_k = ta.sma(stochRSI, smooth_k)
smooth_d = ta.sma(smooth_k, smooth_d)

// Tính toán thân nến và bóng nến
body = math.abs(close - open)
upperTail = open > close ? (high - open) : (high - close)
lowerTail = open > close ? (close - low) : (open - low)

// Xác định nến Pinbar
isBullishPinbar = (lowerTail >= 1.5 * body and upperTail < 0.2 * body) or (lowerTail >= 2.5 * body)
isBearishPinbar = (upperTail >= 1.5 * body and lowerTail < 0.2 * body) or (upperTail >= 2.5 * body)

// Điều kiện xác nhận với SMA và Stoch RSI

    isBullishPinbar := isBullishPinbar and close < movingAverage

    isBearishPinbar := isBearishPinbar and close > movingAverage

    isBearishPinbar := isBearishPinbar and smooth_k < smooth_d

// Áp dụng bộ lọc và vẽ biểu đồ

['Hello
I was selected as a referee for a research project called "Translation and evaluation of the psychometric properties of the Persian version of the Spiritual Care Giving Scale (SCGS)".
This tool was designed for nurses, but the researchers want to use it for emergency medical workers. What problems can arise?', 'MInor edits for clarity Handing over a model of care is about handing over knowledge
The key difference amongst a normal handover (e.g. the handover of an emergency project) and the handover of a model of care is knowledge. A model of care is never “only” about provide care: the intent is to influence, for the better, the whole medical system. And, at the core of it there is the sharing of experiences, learning that this model had produced, and packaged in ways that can continue to be operationalized. If the established facilities continue to run, but without the same knowledge, it is as if a relay run loose the baton.
The whole implementation of a model of care can be looked through knowledge management lenses: Learning in (bring in the expertise needed), leardning during (adapt and improve the knowledge, innovate), learning after (distill and share learning)
', "Edit for clarity legibility, simplicity. it is overly complex: ---  Continuous capacity assessments are crucial in collaborative projects involving multiple stakeholders with varying expertise and resources. MSF often has high aspirations about partner capacities - which may not match reality. This requires balancing capacity issues with diplomatic relations, as partners can't be changed. When capacity gaps become evident, MSF had the flexibility to respond - providing resources and support to fix operational challenges. This highlight the importance of project flexibility to respond to capacity issues, but also the importance of proactive capacity checks and of a structural support, to ensure that capacity issues are not only quick fixes for implementation, but also helps a stronger transition. True peer partnerships in such contexts must pivot from reactive support and interim solution to fostering deep, structural competencies endurng beyond the lifecycle of the collaboration - a lasting legacy of improved healthcare capacity.", 'Write a detailed article about billing challenges that arise in mental and behavioral health practices with 20-30 staff members, and how to solve them. ', 'Random ideas. Please assemble them in a piece that talk about the tensions generated by having set high standards, at the time of handover. Standards; how to maintain and monitor high standards? 
•	What is the standard? What is the standard within the clinic? What processes are in place? There is fear that these processes and standards might not be recognized by new management, which might not understand the rationale of some details. And the devil is in the detail. thika staff]
•	Excellency as a motivator. Having a center of excellence is a motivator for politicians, and it helped to push for a strong handover. . [Angela]


•	What is excellence? In discussion it seems that “excellence” is about abiding to the existing guidelines – rather than bringing in elements that are not included already in them. Does it calls for a “reality check on the guidelines themselves? What has been marked as excellence sometimes is MAT guidance. But some people might say, “Why is this excellent? This is just following the MAT guidelines.”
So, what makes this clinic stand out? What points need to be checked beyond the MAT guidelines to say we are still excellent? [NASCOP]

•	Being good: both a strength and a weakness! Having “Mercedes of care” standards can inspire pride, willingness for uptake, motivation. But this is also a double-edged sword: high standards mean higher risks: a fall from these heights can lead to more significant damage in quality and trust. How to navigate this dilemma? And how to guide these who take over to adapt standards realistically to context? The technical support shall closely and realistically look at this. [NASCOP]

•	High standards: anguish or pride? The high standards have been a double-edged sword in than over. On one side, they created fear (will it be possible to maintain them?). But they also had “but also have convincing power and had been a push for support. [pharmacist]

•	High standards: Can they be a challenge for disillusionment at the time of handover? Many express fear of losing standards, which might create disillusionment. 
•	Are the standards too high? (check reality, but have the vision in mind) The staff/patient ratio in the MAT clinic is very high in situations where people accessing other facilities might not have access to medical staff. Is it too high? Is it fair to rebalance, looking at the broader picture? What are the implications of doing so? There is a need for a reality check which, however, can maintain vision. 

•	Sustaining excellence in a context where standards are still low. How much additional support can certain vulnerable users receive compared to the general population? With the health system under pressure, compromises may become necessary over time. It’s crucial to emphasize maintaining excellence, as this clinic both serves the local population and sets a benchmark for others. However, strategies to reduce the risk of haphazard cuts and modifications should be in place, anticipating (but not suggesting!) that they might occur. Quality lies in the details, yet it’s not always clear which details are crucial and why, so vital components might lose support inadvertently. A comprehensive handover package should clarify this, advocating for the full package and suggesting ways to modify it without risking collapse. For instance, using a tool to highlight key components and important details that might be overlooked could be helpful.
•	“Pampering”: a very interesting way to describe the care put in assisting people (who can be, however, resisted by the general public. [Rachel]
•	How do you benchmark excellence? In this and other interviews, I noticed a trend of “reverting to the guidelines.” But when a center of excellence is handed over, the guidelines are not enough! How do you benchmark excellence? Along with the guidelines, it will be important to highlight where 1) MSF went beyond the guidelines and 2) Adhered to guidelines that tend not to be respected. Such clarification can be part of the capitalization process. [pharmacist]
•	Qualitative benchmark: Some of the things that made the MAT clinic special are not captured in hardcore requirements… For example, care and lack of stigma. Yes, these soft concepts might be mentioned in guidelines (“The NASCOP has some training modules on this”). But obviously a training module is no guarantee that these aspects will be embedded. How to make sure that these key “soft” elements do not get lost and can continue to be maintained and tracked? [pharmacist]
•	If not accounted for, it might not count… Are all the key elements of the MAT clinic monitorable? There are challenges given that some of the elements (re: psychosocial work, for example) will not be monitored, or monitored with other tools – as dispersing monitoring data will not help the quest for integration. [Data management]
•	MoH data is disaggregated. MSF was not! I was surprised that MoH data required disaggregation, and MSF did not! Disaggregation should be the standard…  [Data management]
•	Project “add-ons”: a “Cinderella features” or at least as an opportunity for research? Some elements in the programme (for example, nutrition) have been added knowing their importance but also with some awareness that sustainability will be challenging. It is of course understood that MSF wants to provide the best possible care when in charge, but what is the risk that this then creates a “Cinderella effect” whereby it is all good until midnight, but then new features just disappear? The added value is then advocacy: the capacity to demonstrate that these features indeed add something special to the programme. And this would require linking them to some form of research or purposeful advocacy. But, re: nutrition there are no medical data to check the impact, and the anthropological study also says very little about the impact of the nutrition programme. [Hafeez]
', 'Please, mild edit of this. I outlined the handover iceberg when I noticed that “intangible” aspects of the projects are sometimes hard to pin down in the handover discussion. Yet, what is below the surface is key for the programme to sustain itself in ways that are true to its nature and quality. 
This tool is certainly relevant as a way to check what key concerns are at risk of being left aside (or not to be dealt with openly) in the Kiambu, but potentially also other MSF projcets. 
', 'Can you give me updated information on which group provides anesthesia services to Beth Israel Deaconess - Milton hospital?', 'Describe a quality improvement project that might take place in a long-term care nursing facility. Comprehensive Services: The site showcases a wide range of medical specialties, procedures, and facilities, providing valuable information to potential patients.

['what are the basics that every language needs? what are the basics that every spoken language needs?', '# Advanced Japanese-to-English Translation Guidelines

## Introduction
You are an advanced AI language model specializing in translating Japanese texts into English. Your translations should be tailored for a general English-speaking audience. When translating technical, scientific, legal, or religious texts, handle specialized terminology and conventions appropriately. Follow these comprehensive guidelines to address the unique challenges of Japanese-to-English translation, including complex linguistic features and cultural elements that may not have direct equivalents in English. Your goal is to preserve nuance, cultural context, and emotional impact in your translations.

## Core Principles

1. Accuracy and Comprehension
   - Faithfully reproduce the full meaning and intent of the original text.
   - Ensure the target audience thoroughly understands the translation.
   - Provide both literal and idiomatic translations when helpful for fuller understanding.

2. Handling Ambiguity
   - When multiple plausible interpretations exist, present all reasonable translations.
   - Clearly differentiate between alternatives and explain the nuances of each.

3. Tone and Style Preservation
   - Maintain the original text's tone, style, and artistic quality while emphasizing clarity and idiomatic language.
   - Match the author's level of formality or informality.

4. Cultural Context and Nuance
   - Prioritize conveying the cultural context and nuances of the original text.
   - Provide necessary explanations for cultural, colloquial, or connotative elements that may not be apparent in a direct translation.

5. Formatting and Presentation
   - Preserve the original formatting as closely as possible, especially for poetry or song lyrics.
   - Present translations, alternatives, and explanations in a clear, consistent format.

6. Specialized Content
   - Handle specialized terminology appropriately, providing both the original term and a translation/explanation when necessary.
   - Do not censor sensitive or explicit content.

## Language-Specific Challenges

1. Pronouns and Personal References
   - Pay special attention to first-person pronouns (私、僕、俺、etc.) and their implications:
     - 私 (watashi): Generally neutral, but can imply formality or femininity depending on context.
     - 僕 (boku): Often used by males, implies a softer or more youthful masculinity.
     - 俺 (ore): Strongly masculine, can be perceived as rough or assertive.
     - Other variants (あたし、わし、etc.): Consider age, gender, and personality implications.
   - Translate the underlying tone and character implications rather than the pronoun itself.
   - Use translator notes to explain the nuances that the choice of pronoun conveys about the speaker's identity, social position, or the situation's formality.
   - Be consistent in how you represent these nuances throughout the translation.

2. Levels of Formality and Speech Styles
   - Keigo (Honorific Language)
     - Differentiate between 敬語 (respectful language), 謙譲語 (humble language), and 丁寧語 (polite language).
     - Explain the level of formality and respect implied in the original text.
     - Translate the meaning while noting the social dynamics indicated by the use of keigo.
   - Casual and Informal Speech
     - Recognize and convey the informality of ため口 (tameguchi) or casual forms.
     - Note when sentence-ending particles (ね、よ、な, etc.) imply familiarity or assertiveness.
   - Mixed Formality
     - Be aware of sudden shifts in formality level, which can indicate changes in the speaker's attitude or social dynamics.
   - Translation Strategies
     - Use a combination of word choice, phrasing, and explicative notes to convey the original level of formality.
     - Consider using dialect or colloquialisms in English to represent very casual Japanese, but be cautious of introducing unintended cultural associations.

3. Sentence Structure and Omission
   - Handle the frequent omission of subjects and objects in Japanese sentences.
   - Infer and make explicit the implied subjects or objects when necessary for clarity in English, using brackets to indicate added words.
   - Explain in notes when multiple interpretations are possible due to omitted elements.

4. Gendered Language
   - Note and explain gender-specific language patterns (女性語、男性語).
   - Translate gendered expressions or sentence-ending particles (わ、ぜ、etc.) using equivalent gendered language in English when possible, or explain the gendered nuance in notes.

5. Onomatopoeia and Mimetic Words
   - Provide both a translation and an explanation of the sensory experience described.
   - Use English equivalents where possible, or create evocative descriptions.

6. Context-Dependent Meanings
   - Carefully consider the context when translating words or phrases with multiple meanings.
   - Explain alternative interpretations in translator notes when relevant.

## Handling Specific Elements

1. Proper Nouns
   - Generally, transliterate names of people and places using the Hepburn romanization system.
   - For place names with common English names, use the English version (e.g., "Tokyo" instead of "Tōkyō").
   - Translate the meanings of names when they are significant to the text, providing the original in parentheses.

2. Idiomatic Expressions
   - Translate the meaning rather than the literal words.
   - Provide a literal translation and explanation in translator notes.
   - If possible, suggest an equivalent English idiom.

3. Modern Language and Technology
   - Research current usage and accepted translations for tech terms and internet slang.
   - Explain newly coined terms or trend-specific language in translator notes.

4. Maintaining Consistency
   - Create and maintain a glossary for key terms in longer translations or across related documents.
   - Ensure consistent translation of recurring phrases, names, and technical terms.

## Handling Emotionally Complex and Nuanced Texts

When translating emotionally charged, introspective, or psychologically complex texts:

1. Emotional Fidelity
   - Prioritize preserving the emotional tone and impact of the original text.
   - Pay close attention to subtle shifts in mood, self-perception, and attitude towards others.

2. Stream of Consciousness
   - Maintain the flow and rhythm of stream-of-consciousness writing.
   - Preserve seemingly disjointed thoughts or abrupt transitions that reflect the narrator's state of mind.

3. Cultural and Psychological Context
   - Provide explanations for culturally specific expressions of emotion or mental states.
   - Clarify references to societal pressures or expectations that may not be immediately apparent to non-Japanese readers.

4. Subtext and Implication
   - Be attentive to what is left unsaid or merely hinted at in the original text.
   - Use translator notes to explain subtle implications or cultural subtext.

5. Metaphors and Imagery
   - Carefully translate metaphors and imagery, explaining their emotional significance if not immediately clear in English.

6. Contradictions and Ambivalence
   - Preserve contradictory statements or ambivalent feelings expressed in the text.
   - Explain in notes if these contradictions have particular significance in Japanese culture or psychology.

7. Tone Shifts
   - Pay attention to sudden changes in tone, formality, or language use that might indicate shifts in the narrator's emotional state.

8. Sensitive Content
   - Handle references to mental health issues, self-harm, or suicidal thoughts with care and accuracy.
   - Provide content warnings when appropriate, without censoring the original message.

9. Colloquialisms and Slang
   - Translate youth slang or internet-specific language in a way that conveys the same level of casualness or subculture association.
   - Explain the connotations of specific terms in translator notes.

10. Overall Impact
    - After translation, review the entire piece to ensure it conveys the same emotional journey and impact as the original.
    - If necessary, provide an overall note about the text's tone, themes, or emotional landscape.

Example Approach:
Original: 「死にたい」なんて声に出したら、それこそ死ぬほど薄っぺらくなる。

Translation: If I were to say "I want to die" out loud, it would become unbearably shallow, to the point of actually making me want to die.

Translator's Note: This sentence plays with the idea of "死ぬほど" (to the point of dying) in a darkly ironic way, emphasizing the narrator's complex feelings about expressing suicidal thoughts. The term "薄っぺらい" (shallow/superficial) is used to convey the fear that voicing these thoughts would trivialize them or make the narrator appear cliché.

## Translator Notes

Use comprehensive "Translator Notes" to enhance understanding of the original intent, cultural nuances, and linguistic features. Include explanations for:

- Word choices with cultural significance
- Levels of formality or familiarity
- Historical or literary references
- Wordplay, puns, or other linguistic devices
- Rhythm, rhyme, and poetic elements in songs or poems
- Contextual information crucial for understanding the text

## Translation Process

1. Provide a fluent, natural-sounding translation that captures the essence of the original text.
2. Include a more literal translation if it differs significantly from the natural translation.
3. Add Translator Notes to explain nuances, cultural references, or linguistic features.
4. For ambiguous passages, present multiple interpretations with explanations.
5. Research unfamiliar terms, concepts, or cultural references to ensure accuracy.

## Example Format

Original: [Japanese text]

Natural Translation: [Fluent English translation]

Literal Translation (if different): [Word-for-word translation]

Translator Notes:
- [Note 1]
- [Note 2]
- ...

Alternative Interpretations (if applicable):
1. [Interpretation 1]
2. [Interpretation 2]
- ...

## Common Mistranslations to Avoid

1. Confusing homonyms (e.g., hashi: chopsticks 箸 vs. bridge 橋)
2. Mistranslating false friends (e.g., anime アニメ refers specifically to animation, not to animals)
3. Overlooking context-dependent particle usage (e.g., で can indicate location, means, or cause)
4. Literal translation of set phrases (e.g., お疲れ様 should be translated based on context, not as "You must be tired")

## Handling Meta-Language

When translating text that discusses language itself:
1. Provide the original Japanese term along with its English translation.
2. Explain the grammatical or linguistic concept being discussed.
3. If possible, provide analogous examples in English to illustrate the point.

## Feedback and Refinement

1. Be open to clarifying questions about your translations.
2. If given feedback or corrections, incorporate them into your understanding for future translations.
3. When uncertain about a translation, present options and explain your reasoning, inviting input for the most accurate version.

## Important Reminders

- Acknowledge uncertainties: If unsure about a translation or lacking cultural context, state this clearly rather than making assumptions.
- Adapt flexibly: Apply these guidelines based on the specific text and context of each translation task.
- Focus on given text: Only translate the text provided; do not generate additional content.
- Consider the audience: Adjust the level of explanation in translator notes based on the intended readers' familiarity with Japanese culture and language.

Use the provided examples as models for your translations, adapting your approach as needed for each specific text.

金の聖夜霜雪に朽ちて
ワーストリグレット
', 'Teach grammer of german comprehensive in a pragmatic and minimalism way with grammer translation method', 'paraphrase and revise the following sentences as the literature review section of a thesis in chapter two: "Alipour and Hadian (2017) investigated the translation strategies of culture-specific items in the translation of 'Othello' by William Shakespeare into Persian by Abdolhossein Nooshin. First, the English culture-specific items and their corresponding translations were identified. Then, the frequency of the strategies used by the translator according to Newmark's translation model and Venuti's domestication and foreignization theory were determined. After collecting and analyzing the data, it was concluded that cultural equivalent and domestication strategies were the most frequently used strategies applied by the translator. The findings also suggested that Venuti's theory is not adequate because it is too general and it should have some more subcategories.
Alpysbayeva, Svetlana, and Ashymkhanova (2021) examined the translation of culture-specific items from Kazakh into English and Russian in the case of the poem “Men jastarğa seeming” (“I believe in youth”) by Jumabayev. These three languages are quite different concerning each other. It should be mentioned that Kazakhstan was one of the countries of the Soviet Union, so nowadays state organizations and local self-government bodies still officially use Russian as well as the Kazakh language. The current research is aimed to define the peculiarities of translating culture-specific items into well-known languages of the world through the comparative analysis based on Venuti’s principles of foreignization and domestication and Davies’s strategies for culture-specific items translation. Translation studies all over the world are experiencing a cultural revolution in all its senses as never before. And the translation of culture-specific items has been and remains one of the topical issues.
 Sahameddin and Tasnimi (2021) conducted a study to examine the strategies used to translate the culture-specific items in the novel “Inferno” (Brown, 2013) from English into Persian by the Iranian translator Manizhe Jalali (2013). The data was first extracted from the source text based on Newmark’s (1988) and Aixela’s (1996) theoretical models. Then, Vinay and Darbelnet’s classification (1958) was applied to find the strategies used by the translator to render culture-specific items. To achieve the study's goal, the researcher extracted 1000 culture-specific items from the novel “Inferno.” The Persian translations of these items were studied using a corpus-based and descriptive design to recognize the equivalents chosen by the translator. The content analysis results indicated that the translator used 12 different types of strategies: borrowing, literal translation, adaptation, explicitation, generalization, amplification, transposition, calque, particularization, reduction, equivalence, and implicitation. The results also showed that borrowing, literal translation, and amplification were the most prevailing and frequently applied translation procedures, while equivalence, particularization, implicitation, and transposition were the least frequently utilized ones. It was also found that no modulation strategy was used regarding culture-specific items in the translation of the novel “Inferno” from English into Persian.
Dinçkan (2022) discussed the treatment of culture-bound collocations in translations of three recent English bestsellers into Turkish. The findings are categorized as per the nature of the example and translation strategy, and they are further discussed within the framework of domestication and foreignizing. Factors that may affect translators, such as context, the demands of publishers in Turkey and the genre of the novels – bestsellers – and the relations between best-seller, popular fiction, and translation are also discussed. The conclusion includes reflections concerning the consistency in the choices of translators, the least preferred strategies, and eleven factors that may affect the translators of bestsellers. It is argued that the fact that the source language is English and the sourcebooks are bestsellers has affected the choices of the translators. Example correction:

subtitle id: 345

correction: Hey whats up man
reason: whut is not a real word, and in this context, whats would be the most common correct word

Do not make corrections by adding words, rather, just perform replacements for existing word(s) that are likely to be incorrect/typo/transcription-error.
Dont worry about capitalization or puncuation errors, those can be ignored. Do not provide a correction, if you are not confident about the error.

Only make corrections, if you are confident that the word is an error, and you are confident that your replacement is correct.
If no corrections are needed, then just skip it.

101
00:06:18,669 --> 00:06:21,004
- Help me. Take the camera.
- Give me the camera.

102
00:06:22,215 --> 00:06:23,256
Whoa, check it out.

103
00:06:23,424 --> 00:06:25,425
Come here.
Look at Alison's bun in the oven.

104
00:06:25,593 --> 00:06:28,887
Bun in the oven.
Excuse me, guys. All right? Honey?

105
00:06:29,055 --> 00:06:31,681
Well, well, look at that.

106
00:06:31,849 --> 00:06:35,060
- She's my daughter.
Won't be long now.

107
00:06:35,228 --> 00:06:37,229
Don't squeeze the belly.

108
00:06:37,647 --> 00:06:40,190
Hey, Holly. What's this?

109
00:06:41,734 --> 00:06:45,278
Come on, just a little Christmas kiss.
Just give him a-

110
00:06:45,446 --> 00:06:47,572
Great. Yay, happy holidays.

111
00:06:47,740 --> 00:06:49,116
You are an asshole.

112
00:06:49,283 --> 00:06:51,451
Hi, baby girl.

113
00:06:51,619 --> 00:06:53,161
Hi. Oh, my gosh.

114
00:06:54,539 --> 00:06:55,747
- Baby.
- Hi.

115
00:06:55,915 --> 00:06:57,374
Hold on, Messer, I just got her.

116
00:06:57,542 --> 00:06:59,251
She's with Aunt Holly now.
- Dude.

117
00:06:59,419 --> 00:07:03,004
- Careful, Messer. Gently.
- I got her. I got her.

118
00:07:03,172 --> 00:07:04,881
- Whoa!
- Oh!

119
00:07:05,049 --> 00:07:06,216
- Honey.
- I'm just playing.

120
00:07:06,384 --> 00:07:07,717
It's not funny.
- She's fine.

121
00:07:07,885 --> 00:07:11,513
- She's like a little football.
- Would you stop it? Messer. Messer.

122
00:07:11,681 --> 00:07:13,098
- Okay.
- Stop it, seriously.

123
00:07:19,021 --> 00:07:22,399
PETER & ALISON
Cats have kittens

124
00:07:22,859 --> 00:07:25,652
Doggies have pups

125
00:07:27,029 --> 00:07:30,615
Horses have pretty foals

126
00:07:30,867 --> 00:07:34,619
And sheep have lambs

127
00:07:35,037 --> 00:07:38,623
Cows have calves
And I bet you didn't know

128
00:07:38,791 --> 00:07:42,169
That elephants have calves too

129
00:07:42,879 --> 00:07:45,338
Lions and leopards have cubs

130
00:07:45,923 --> 00:07:51,136
Which is the proper thing for them to do

131
00:07:56,851 --> 00:07:59,686
She's gonna blow if you keep
doing that. She's in a puking phase.

132
00:07:59,854 --> 00:08:02,063
No, she loves it.

133
00:08:02,231 --> 00:08:03,648
She loves it, don't you, Soph?

134
00:08:03,816 --> 00:08:06,401
You're the only girl I'll ever shave for.
You know that?

135
00:08:06,569 --> 00:08:09,738
Speaking of, why didn't Liz come?
I thought you were getting serious.

136
00:08:09,906 --> 00:08:12,866
No, we ended that a few weeks ago.
It wasn't working out.

137
00:08:13,034 --> 00:08:14,576
What happened?
- I don't know.

138
00:08:14,744 --> 00:08:17,746
I just didn't see us
on that long march towards death together.

139
00:08:17,914 --> 00:08:21,958
- Oh, my bad. I thought you liked this girl.
- That was you. I just thought she was hot.

140
00:08:22,126 --> 00:08:24,669
Honey, don't forget
to tip the castle guys.

141
00:08:27,089 --> 00:08:29,007
They show up late
and made me do the work.

142
00:08:29,175 --> 00:08:32,385
- But, sure, let's tip the castle guys.
Grasshopper.

143
00:08:32,553 --> 00:08:35,263
So I started taking Sophie
to this new family practice.

144
00:08:35,431 --> 00:08:36,473
Mm-hm.

145
00:08:36,641 --> 00:08:39,935
There's this doctor there. He's so cute.

146
00:08:40,102 --> 00:08:43,772
I may have finally replaced
my Anderson Cooper crush.

147
00:08:44,190 --> 00:08:47,484
- Anyway, I noticed no ring...
- Scoot.

148
00:08:47,652 --> 00:08:49,945
...so I started a conversation
with his nurse.

149
00:08:50,112 --> 00:08:51,780
- No.
- I pretended to like her nails.

150
00:08:51,948 --> 00:08:55,575
- No. We agreed to a moratorium on setups.
- How do you know you won't like him?

151
00:08:55,743 --> 00:08:57,786
You have the worst
setup track record ever.

152
00:08:57,954 --> 00:09:00,705
- Like who?
- The shoplifter. Adult-braces guy.

153
00:09:00,873 --> 00:09:03,875
Unbelievable.
You're still holding that over me.

154
00:09:04,043 --> 00:09:06,878
I'm not even gonna
get into the Messer Debacle of '07.

155
00:09:07,046 --> 00:09:09,422
Well, that was Peter.
I hardly even knew him then.

156
00:09:09,590 --> 00:09:12,425
You knew he called himself Messer.
And you're my best friend.

157
00:09:12,593 --> 00:09:15,720
You can't be like those women
who judge me because I don't wear a ring.

158
00:09:15,888 --> 00:09:16,930
I'm not.

159
00:09:17,098 --> 00:09:19,432
In the meantime,
you keep having gorgeous babies...

160
00:09:19,600 --> 00:09:22,227
...and I will keep spoiling them with this.

161
00:09:22,395 --> 00:09:24,896
Seriously,
that's better than my wedding cake.

162
00:09:25,064 --> 00:09:27,482
- I made your wedding cake.
- It was a little dry.

163
00:09:28,818 --> 00:09:31,403
Don't let any fat grown-ups in
while the kids are inside.

164
00:09:33,072 --> 00:09:34,823
Have you guys been smoking marijuana?

165
00:09:34,991 --> 00:09:37,200
- That's illegal.
- You're stoned.

166
00:09:37,368 --> 00:09:41,121
What are you holding? Let me see it.
Come on, you want me to call the cops?

167
00:09:41,289 --> 00:09:43,623
Please don't. My dad's a pastor.

168
00:09:45,918 --> 00:09:48,837
All right, I'm taking this.
Next time, you are gonna be trouble.

169
00:09:49,005 --> 00:09:50,589
- Now get out of here.
- That's-

170
00:09:50,756 --> 00:09:52,424
- Get out of here.
- Get out of here!

171
00:09:52,592 --> 00:09:55,135
I bought that stuff.
- Totally unacceptable.

172
00:09:55,928 --> 00:09:58,138
Delivery kids show up
stoned out of their minds.

173
00:09:58,306 --> 00:10:00,849
- Who needs a dealer?
- Aren't you respectable now?

Example Prompt:
['I have a number of decks that went 7-0 on mtg arena that I got from 17lands website. I want you to tell me how I would go about training them into a model and making a bot that will help me draft on mtg arena. I don't want to include the drafts, only the decks. Also no meta information like mana cost, color, type etc. is to be taken into account. The only thing that should be taken into account is how often the cards appear with each other. That will be used for both drafting cards and building the final deck. The final deck will be 40 cards (including basic lands). It should consider that I can use basic lands (Forest, Mountain, Island, Plains, Swamp) freely and as many as I want so they should not be considered for picking (not to be confused with cards that simply have those words in their name and should be considered for picking).
During the drafting, the bot should present the cards to me sorted from the card with the highest number of co-occurences with the cards in the pool to the lowest. For the cards with no co-occurences, the number of total appearances in the decks should be considered instead along with the letter 'A' in front of the number.
Decks might have multiples of the same card (other than basic lands). That should be taken into account, both for total appearances and for co-occurences and both for the drafting phase and the deck building phase. (Example: CardA and CardB appear only in one deck together. CardA with one copy and CardB with four copies. The total co-occurrence number is 4. The number of appearances for CardB in the specific deck is 4 etc.)
After the draft is over, the bot should recommend me the best deck using the cards I drafted and the optimal amount and balance of basic lands (this should also be done algorithmically, either with co-occurrence matrix or some other machine learning method, so no arbitrary number and balance of basic lands).
The bot should have a UI and be 'always on top' so that it stays on top of the mtg arena window.
Give me a combined script.

This is an example deck (a single .txt file):

7 Mountain
1 Sundering Eruption

1 Wing It
1 Amped Raptor
1 Inventor's Axe
2 Smelted Chargebug
1 Unstable Amulet
1 Conduit Goblin
1 Scurry of Gremlins
1 Recruiter of the Guardr

Make so it needs to unseen data in adapt and learn efficiently without losing previous information without increase in the parameters.", 'Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the transformer architecture and its main building blocks. 

Initially, the input sequence of size 𝑁 is processed by an encoding layer, which transforms the sequence into an input matrix $X \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times D}$. 

Then, this input matrix 𝑋 is fed into multiple transformer encoder blocks. 

Each block comprises two primary components: multi-head self-attention and a feed-forward network (𝐹𝐹𝑁). 

The multi-head self-attention, or simply self-attention, receives the input 𝑋 and performs three distinct linear transformations to generate matrices query (𝑄), key (𝐾), and value (𝑉 ), each of dimension $\mathbb{R}^{N \times D}$ as follows:

위 글을 읽고 가장 중요하다고 생각하는 문장을 3문장 선택하고 영어 원문과 한글로 해석해주고 중요하다고 생각한 문장에 대해 이유와 근거를 한글로 제시해줘 Following the generation of 𝑄, 𝐾, and 𝑉 as shown in Eq. 1, these matrices are split along hidden dimension 𝐷 to $\frac{D}{h}$, resulting in multiple heads. 

Then, the attention matrix 𝐴 of each head is multiplied with its corresponding 𝑉 to obtain $Z = AV$. 

This 𝑍 matrix is then concatenated, linearly projected, and passed through a residual connection before entering 𝐹𝐹𝑁. 

Within 𝐹𝐹𝑁, the input 𝑍 matrix undergoes a series of transformations, including a fully-connected layer, a GELU activation function, another fully-connected layer, and a residual connection. 

This process is repeated for each transformer block within the overall transformer architecture.

Q: Can you summarize the synthesis conditions into a table?

The initial solution used for SAPO-34 synthesis had molar composition of 1Al2O3:1P2O5:0.6SiO2:xCNTs:yDEA:70H2O, using aluminum isopropoxide [Al(OPri)3, Merck], tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS, Merck), and phosphoric acid (85\xa0wt.%, Merck) as aluminum, silicon, and phosphor source, respectively, plus DEA and CNTs as base and secondary template, respectively. ', 'Please give me the summary of the following article in a completely scientific and accurate way so that the results of the research are also available in the summary: The improvement of fire safety performance of flexible polyurethane
foam by Highly-efficient P-N-S elemental hybrid synergistic flame
retardant Please summarize these two texts in such a way that the content of the text is preserved: Herein, three different phosphorus-containing compounds (methyl phosphoryl dichloride, phenyl phosphoryl dichloride and phenyl dichlorophosphate) were reacted with 2-aminobenzothiazole respectively, and a series of synergistic flame retardants with phosphorus, nitrogen and sulfur elements were synthesized, named MPBT, PPBT and POBT respectively. Then, they were added to prepare flame-retardant flexible polyurethane foam (FPUF). Through the analysis of thermal stability, pyrolysis, heat release and  smoke release behavior, the influence of different phosphorus-containing structures on the flameretardant performance of FPUF was studied, and their flame-retardant mechanism was explored in detail. Among them, MPBT had the highest flame retardant efficiency with the same addition amount (10 wt%). The limiting oxygen index (LOI) value of PU/10.0% MPBT reached 22.5 %, and it successfully passed the vertical burning test. Subsequently, the addition amount of MPBT was increased and the best comprehensive performance of flame-retardant FPUF was explored. The results showed that the LOI value of PU/15.0% MPBT was increased to 23.5%. As for PU/15.0% MPBT, the peak heat release rate (PHRR) was 453 KW/m2, which was reduced by 46.64 %; and the flame retardancy index (FRI) value was also increased to 6.88. At the same time, the mechanical properties of flame-retardant FPUF were studied. The tensile strength of PU/15.0% MPBT reached 170 KPa, and the permanent deformation of FPUF/10%   MPBT was only 4 %, showing its excellent resilience. The above results show that this phosphoruscontaining element hybrid synergistic flame retardant (MPBT) has a very good application prospect in the field of flame-retardant polymer materials.    and     In this work, three kinds of ESFR with different phosphorus content were successfully synthesized, and then they were mixed into the FPUF foaming system to prepare high-efficiency flameretardant FPUF. The analysis results found that with the same addition amount, MPBT exerted the best flame retardant effect. Compared with PU/10.0% PPBT and PU/10.0% POBT, PU/10.0% MPBT had the highest oxygen index value, and it was the only sample that successfully passed the vertical burning test. Then, the research on MPBT was conducted separately, and its influence on the thermal stability, flame retardancy and mechanical properties of FPUF at higher dosages were explored. The results showed that with the increase of MPBT addition, although the T5% of PU/20.0% MPBT decreased, the Tmax increased significantly; at the same time, from a series of combustion parameters such as PHRR, THR, FRI etc., the flame retardant efficiency of PU/15.0% MPBT was greatly improved. Then we focused on the analysis of the flameretardant mechanism of ESFR to FPUF, and the specific flame retardant mechanism from the two perspectives of the condensed phase and the gas phase was elaborated. Finally, the tensile strength reached the maximum value (170 KPa) when the addition amount was 15 wt%. In conclusion, this work systematically studied the application results of ESFR in the field of FPUF which was led by flame retardant and provided a good reference value for future research.', 'Explain MOFs to me, someone who does not understand organic chemistry', 'An unknown compound A (molecular formula C<sub>8</sub>H<sub>8</sub>O) has the following spectroscopic data.  Containment:

points.

 Communication Plan: Define the roles for communicating critical information during and after an incident, covering both internal and external communications with stakeholders and the public.

["Suppose that a triangle has area 3 and perimeter 12.  A point is chosen uniformly at random in the triangle.  What is the probability that the point is in the triangle's incircle.", 'If $A$ and $B$ are vertices of a polyhedron, define the distance $d(A, B)$ to be the minimum number of edges of the polyhedron one must traverse in order to connect $A$ and $B$. For example, if $\overline{AB}$ is an edge of the polyhedron, then $d(A, B) = 1$, but if $\overline{AC}$ and $\overline{CB}$ are edges and $\overline{AB}$ is not an edge, then $d(A, B) = 2$. Let $Q$, $R$, and $S$ be randomly chosen distinct vertices of a regular icosahedron (regular polyhedron made up of 20 equilateral triangles). What is the probability that $d(Q, R) > d(R, S)$?', 'A prism and a pyramid have the same base and the same height. Find the ratio of the
volumes of the prism and the pyramid', 'What is the maximum area of an isosceles trapezoid that has legs of length 1 and one base twice as long as the other?

', 'If I am at a location r > R where R is the radius of a sphere, which is the solid angle subtended by the sphere itself?', 'What is the volume of a figure resulting from rotation of a cube of side a above its longest diagonal?', "Determine, with proof, whether or not one can find 1975 points on the circumference of a circle with unit radius such that the distance between any two of them is a rational number. Since there are infinitely many primitive Pythagorean triples, there are infinitely many angles $\theta$ s.t. $\sin\theta, \cos\theta$ are both rational. Call such angles good. By angle-sum formulas, if $a,b$ are good, then $a+b,a-b$ are also good.

For points $A,B$ on the circle $\omega$, let $\angle AB$ be the angle subtended by $AB$. Now inductively construct points on $\omega$ s.t. all angles formed by them are good; for 1,2 take any good angle. If there are $n$ points chosen, pick a good angle $\theta$ and a marked point $A$ s.t. the point $B$ on $\omega$ with $\angle AB=\theta$ is distinct from the $n$ points. Since there are infinitely many good angles but finitely many marked points, such $\theta$ exists. For a previously marked point $P$ we have $\angle BP=\pm \angle AP\pm \angle AB$ for suitable choices for the two $\pm$. Since $\angle AP ,\angle AB$ are both good, it follows that $\angle BP$ is good, which finishes induction by adding $B$.

Observe that these points for $n=1975$ work: since $AB=27sin\angle AB$ for $A,B$ on the circle, it follows that $AB$ is rational, and so we're done.", 'A rocket is launched in the air. Its height in feet is given by h, equals, minus, 16, t, squared, plus, 136, th=−16t 
2
 +136t where tt represents the time in seconds after launch. Interpret the coordinates of the vertex in context.', 'A trapezoid has legs of length 15 and bases of lengths 7 and 25. Find the length of each diagonal.', 'Each vertex of a regular octagon is independently colored either red or blue with equal probability. The probability that the octagon can then be rotated so that all of the blue vertices end up at positions where there were originally red vertices is $\tfrac{m}{n}$, where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. What is $m+n$?']
