import { Application, Assets, Sprite, Point } from 'pixi.js';

(async () =>
{
    // Create a new application
    const app = new Application();

    // Initialize the application
    await app.init({ resizeTo: window });

    // Append the application canvas to the document body
    document.body.appendChild(app.canvas);

    // Load textures
    await Assets.load([
        'https://pixijs.com/assets/bg_plane.jpg',
        'https://pixijs.com/assets/cells.png',
        'https://pixijs.com/assets/flowerTop.png',
    ]);

    app.stage.eventMode = 'static';

    const bg = Sprite.from('https://pixijs.com/assets/bg_plane.jpg');

    app.stage.addChild(bg);

    const cells = Sprite.from('https://pixijs.com/assets/cells.png');

    cells.scale.set(1.5);

    const mask = Sprite.from('https://pixijs.com/assets/flowerTop.png');

    mask.anchor.set(0.5);
    mask.x = 310;
    mask.y = 190;

    cells.mask = mask;

    app.stage.addChild(mask, cells);

    const target = new Point();

    reset();

    function reset()
    {
        target.x = Math.floor(Math.random() * 550);
        target.y = Math.floor(Math.random() * 300);
    }

    // Animate the mask
    app.ticker.add(() =>
    {
        mask.x += (target.x - mask.x) * 0.1;
        mask.y += (target.y - mask.y) * 0.1;

        if (Math.abs(mask.x - target.x) < 1)
        {
            reset();
        }
    });
})();
"]

Category: Scientific Research and Analysis in Biomedical and Life Sciences
OpenAI:
['Here is the streamlined abstract:

Quantifying mutational processes in mammalian cells is vital for understanding cancer evolution and personalized medicine, yet remains challenging due to the lack of robust methodologies. This study addresses this gap by adapting sequencing-based fluctuation assays with the Luria-Delbrück approach and advanced sequencing techniques. Our pipeline includes mutation-accumulation lines for rigorous control and mathematical models that consider population dynamics for precise mutation rate inference. The method relies on three core elements: estimating the Luria-Delbrück spectrum of subclonal mutations, modeling sequencing-read sampling errors, and detecting subclonal mutations. Removing any of these components results in dramatic inaccuracies. Our models also establish general sampling bounds on sequencing depth and sampled bases, facilitating accurate mutation rate measurement in various systems, including yeast. This framework marks significant progress toward tools applicable directly to cancer patient data.

Streamlined paragraph:

Detecting selective forces in a population requires an accurate neutral model to describe mutation accumulation without selection, helping identify deviations signaling selective pressure. The evolution mode depends on mutation rate: low rates lead to periodic selection, where mutations fix without interference, while high rates cause clonal interference with competing beneficial mutations, preventing all from fixation. These regimes inform strategies to mitigate drug resistance, underscoring the need for precise mutation rate estimation.

Short survey paragraph:

Different methods have been explored for quantifying mutation rates in cancer systems, each with distinct advantages and limitations. Comparative genomics, using pairwise genome distances, leverages extensive data but is confounded by evolutionary factors and long-timescale assumptions. Mutation Accumulation Lines (MALs) offer direct mutation rate measurement under minimal selection but are labor-intensive. Lineage sequencing provides high-resolution somatic mutation detection down to single cells but demands accurate lineage reconstruction, often challenged by low mutation rates. Other approaches focus on analyzing clonal mutations under cytotoxic stress or using CRISPR to study mutational signatures, with varying degrees of focus on quantification accuracy. Integrating these diverse methods could enhance understanding of mutation processes in cancer systems.

Topic label:
Mutation Rate Quantification in Cancer']

  Despite its significance in understanding cancer evolution and
  personalized medicine, quantifying mutational processes in mammalian
  cells remains challenging.
  % 
  % In microorganisms, the quantification of accumulated mutations is

  % and mathematical models
  %

%
  We bridge this gap by adapting sequencing-based fluctuation assays,

  sequencing techniques. Our pipeline incorporates
  mutation-accumulation lines as a rigorous control, and leverages
  mathematical models that account for population dynamics to ensure
  accurate inference.
  %
  Our method is based on three main ingredients. First, a quantitative
  estimate of the Luria-Delbr\"uck spectrum of subclonal mutations;
  second, a rigorous statistical  model for sequencing-read sampling
  and sequencing errors; third,  a data-analysis pipeline for the
  detection of subclonal mutations 
  %
  We show how releasing any of these ingredients  can lead to  erroneous
  estimates of the mutation rate by several orders of magnitude.
  %
  Additionally, our models provide general and precise sampling bounds
  on sequencing depth and number of sampled bases necessary to measure
  mutation rates accurately, enabling future work on any system. To
  prove this point, we demonstrate how it is possible to deploy the
  same method for yeast, despite its small genome, provided mutations
  are sampled across tens to hundreds of independent experimental

  %
  Our study demonstrates the robust reliability and applicability of
  this framework, marking a crucial step towards developing tools for
  analyzing methods applicable directly to patients' data.  Can you streamline the following paragraph?

First and foremost, the detection of selective forces in a population
necessitates an appropriate neutral model, which describes the
accumulation of mutations in the absence of selection. Such a model is
pivotal for identifying deviations from neutrality that indicate
selective pressure acting on the population\textcolor{blue}{REFS}.
%
Furthermore, understanding the rate at which selective mutations occur
within an evolving population is essential for defining the mode of
evolution. In scenarios where the mutation rate is low, such that at
any given time there is at most one beneficial mutation, the
population evolves under the periodic selection regime. This regime is
characterized by a series of fixation events that do not interfere
with one another, and where each selective mutation is destined for
fixation\textcolor{blue}{REF}. Conversely, when multiple beneficial
mutations emerge simultaneously, the population experiences clonal
interference. In this regime, beneficial mutations compete with each
other, resulting in a situation where not all mutations reach
fixation\textcolor{blue}{REF}. These theoretical frameworks have been
extensively investigated and have been shown to describe the evolution
and emergence of drug resistance in microbial
populations\textcolor{blue}{REF}. Each evolutionary regime
necessitates different strategies to mitigate the emergence of
resistance, highlighting the importance of precise mutation rate
quantification
\cite{lassig2017predicting,lassig2023steering}%nature eco evo review.
 Please use the following information to write a short paragraph surveying the work performed trying to quantify the mutation rate in mammalian cells and cancer systems. highlighting the limitation of the different approaches

PMID: 21076057
Mutation and epigenetic molecular clocks in cancer
Darryl Shibata

This approach is based on enumerating differences between genomes by a pairwise distance. The advantage of this approach is that it can leverage a large amount of existing genomic data. However, it is subject to confounding factors like selection, ecological interactions, effective population size changes, and other evolutionary processes, which can obscure the true underlying mutational processes. Additionally, it relies on the assumption that mutation patterns and rates are constant over long evolutionary timescales, and can only provide estimates of the average mutation rate over long evolutionary timescales. Finally, it may be difficult to distinguish between germline and somatic mutations in some cases.

Mutation Accumulation Lines (MALs) are laborious but provide a direct experimental measure of the instantaneous mutation rate under minimal selection. Additionally, it allows for the detection of rare mutations that may be missed by comparative genomics approaches, it can distinguish between different mutational processes (e.g., base substitutions, indels) and their relative contributions to the overall mutation rate, and enables a controlled study of the effects of various factors (e.g., environmental conditions, genetic background) on mutation rates.

In summary, comparative genomics and pairwise distances provide a broad, evolutionary perspective on mutation patterns and rates, while MALs offer a more controlled, experimental approach to directly measure mutation rates. Both methods have their strengths and limitations, and a combination of these approaches can provide a more comprehensive understanding of the underlying mutation processes.



PMID: 30459213
Quantification of somatic mutation flow across individual cell division events by lineage sequencing. 
Yehuda Brod et al. (Scott R. Manalis and Paul C. Blainey)

Lineage sequencing genome sequencing approach that offers high resolution in reconstructing somatic events and calls variants at the single-cell level. Single cells with a common lineage structure are collected from a population 

This is similar to the “brother” sequencing approach we have, but aims at quantifying the clonal mutations along lineages, not the subclonal spectrum. This is not a great idea because the number of generations along the lineages are typically short, or subject to non-neutral evolution.  

The method is better than standard sequencing approaches, integrates data from multiple sequence libraries, and has the potential to correlate single-cell phenotypes with mutation data by linking observed phenotypes to the underlying genomic changes. It also allows for assigning mutations to specific lineage segments some flexibility in sampling strategies and developing experimental designs targeted to specific questions. 

A limitation of this method is the necessity to reconstruct accurate lineage information, which can be uncertain in cases with low mutation rates or sparse sampling. Additionally, there is a potential for selection bias at two stages, (1) the choice of lineages for analysis, and (2) the subsampling of cells from a particular lineage. Finally, the small sample size may limit the power to explore the relationship between the number of cell divisions and the number of somatic mutations.

PMID: 27161042
A comprehensive survey of the mutagenic impact of common cancer cytotoxics
Bernadett Szikriszt et al. ( Zoltan Szallasi, Charles Swanton & Dávid Szüts )

This study uses used whole genome sequencing to quantify mutation rate and focuses on single expansions in presence of cytotoxic chemotherapy agents like cisplatin, cyclophosphamide, and etoposide, gemcitabine and doxorubicin in chicken DT40 cells. 

In the study, the spontaneous mutation rate was determined through a mock treatment regimen spanning approximately 100 cell generations, finding a plausible value. Wild-type DT40 cells derived from a single cell clone, were subjected to a mock treatment regimen, three post-treatment cell clones were analyzed for single nucleotide variations (SNVs) and short insertion/deletion mutations using the IsoMut method. This method identifies mutations that are unique to the post-treatment clones and excludes mutations present in the pre-treatment starting clone (this is similar to the lineage sequencing approach). They detected 47 ± 20  novel SNVs in the three post-treatment clones, which were considered as spontaneous mutations that likely arose during the mock treatment. The observed mutation number was projected to the 2.06 × 10^9 base pair diploid genome, equivalent to about 2.3 × 10^(-10) mutations per base per cell division. This value represents the estimated spontaneous mutation rate, but the error is almost 50%. The numbe rof effective generations is also difficult to evaluate, since cell death becomes very important under treatment, and cell-cycle duration is also affected. 

The study uses a different approach compared to a mutation accumulation line setup with bottlenecks. Since the study is focused on chemotherapeutic agents to induce mutations, and no bottleneck, there is strong selection pressure. The study tries to minimize selection by using moderate drug concentrations (IC50) that allow 30-85% cell survival. However, considerable  selection pressure may still be present. Instead, mutation accumulation lines use repeated bottlenecks (ideally single-cell bottlenecks) to minimize selection pressure, allowing mutations to accumulate regardless of their fitness effects, hence focusing on the effect of a treatment on the underlying mutational process 

The study analyzes three post-treatment clones for each drug. Note that this is like considering only the last expansion in our experiment and looking at clonal mutations. In some way their experiment is contained in ours. 

=> we can reanalyze our data quantifying the clonal mutations (compared to reference) of the three brothers, or in any case following their method step by step and  compare the final estimates. This can provide a SI figure and a nice comparison. 


PMID: 28912133
Use of CRISPR-modified human stem cell organoids to study the origin of mutational signatures in cancer
Jarno Drost  et al. (Hans Clevers)

This study developed a strategy to explore the origin of cancer-associated mutational signatures using CRISPR-Cas9  to delete DNA repair genes in human colon organoids, followed by delayed subcloning and whole-genome sequencing. 

The study found that mutation accumulation in organoids deficient in the mismatch repair gene MLH1 is driven by replication errors and accurately models mutation profiles in mismatch repair–deficient colorectal cancers. The application of this strategy to the cancer predisposition gene NTHL1, which encodes a base excision repair protein, revealed a mutational footprint (signature 30) previously observed in a breast cancer cohort. The study showed that signature 30 can arise from germline NTHL1 mutations.

The technique to evaluate mutation rates seems naive (expansion-sequencing for 7-14 days, no bottleneccks, no lineage sequencing, quantification of clonal mutations). They quote it as established in PMID: 25957691. Since they do not focus on quantification but on qualitative comparisons, they induce high mutation rates, analyze signatures, presumably these limitations do not impact the study (but they may).  They do not seem to consider changes in population-dynamics parameters in the  knockouts (but presumably they slow down, so that mutation counts occur in a lower number of generations, so the neglected bias leads to a conservative estimate). 

PMID: 28485371
Differences between germline and somatic mutation rates in humans and mice
Brandon Milholland et al. (Jan Vijg)

The study focuses on comparing somatic mutation rates with germline mutation rates in mice and humans. They estimate somatic mutation rates as nearly two orders of magnitude higher than germline mutation rates, ~ 10−7 per bp per mitosis, which honestly seems suspicious, compared to our estimates. According to their conclusions colorectal cancer should mutate 1-2 orders of magnitude slower than normal cells… The error might be due to an overestimation of the mutations or an underestimation of the number of mitoses. 

Germline mutation rates were determined by comparative genomics, from whole genome sequencing data of family trios, estimating the number of germilne mitoses in men and mice sperms by age. 

The method used for quantifying somatic mutation rates involved isolating primary dermal fibroblasts from a 6-year-old human and a 5-day-old mouse and performing whole genome sequencing of multiple single cells after whole genome amplification from single cells. The results showed a median somatic mutation frequency of ~ 10−7 per bp per mitosis. The method to estimate the number of mitoses involved a rough estimate of the total of cell divisions during development, tissue homoeostasis maintenance, and cell divisions in culture. For human cells, an estimate of 106.6 mitoses was derived based on cell turnover rates and observations in culture. For mice, the estimate was 55 mitoses, considering developmental stages and culture conditions.

#### Strategic Focus and Investment Opportunities

1. **Accelerated Renewable Energy Deployment**:

2. **Advanced Energy Storage Solutions**:
   - **Optimization**: Prioritize investments in long-duration energy storage technologies beyond BESS, such as green hydrogen, to address seasonal variability and enhance grid stability.
   - **Investment Opportunity**: Support startups and research in innovative storage solutions, including flow batteries and thermal storage.

3. **Digitalization and AI Integration**:
   - **Optimization**: Strengthen the integration of AI and IoT in energy management systems to enable predictive maintenance, dynamic pricing, and demand response at a larger scale.
   - **Investment Opportunity**: Invest in companies developing AI platforms for energy management and smart grid technologies.

4. **Regulatory and Market Innovations**:
   - **Optimization**: Advocate for regulatory frameworks that incentivize private investment in renewable energy and storage, including tax credits, feed-in tariffs, and green bonds.
   - **Investment Opportunity**: Participate in policy advocacy and support regulatory sandbox initiatives that test new market mechanisms.

5. **Energy Efficiency and Demand-Side Management**:
   - **Optimization**: Promote energy efficiency as a key component of the energy transition, including retrofitting buildings and implementing smart energy management systems in industries.
   - **Investment Opportunity**: Invest in companies offering energy-efficient technologies and services, including smart home solutions and industrial energy management systems.

6. **International Collaboration and Export Potential**:
   - **Optimization**: Leverage Germany's technological leadership in renewable energy to form international partnerships and export solutions to other countries undergoing similar transitions.
   - **Investment Opportunity**: Explore joint ventures and technology licensing agreements with international partners.

#### Risks and Mitigation Strategies

1. **Policy and Regulatory Uncertainty**:
   - **Mitigation**: Maintain a diversified portfolio across different energy transition sectors to reduce dependency on any single policy outcome.

2. **Technological Risks**:
   - **Mitigation**: Invest in multiple technologies and support research and development to hedge against the risk of any single technology failing to scale.

3. **Market Volatility**:
   - **Mitigation**: Use financial instruments such as futures and options to hedge against commodity price fluctuations and invest in companies with strong balance sheets and low debt.

4. **Supply Chain Disruptions**:
   - **Mitigation**: Diversify supply chains, both geographically and across different suppliers, to reduce vulnerability to trade disputes and natural disasters.

#### Conclusion

Germany's energy transition presents significant investment opportunities, particularly in advanced renewable energy technologies, energy storage, and digital solutions. Investors should focus on sectors with high growth potential and strong government support, while also considering strategies to mitigate risks associated with policy changes, technological uncertainties, and market volatility. By aligning investments with the goals of the Energiewende and leveraging emerging technologies, investors can contribute to a sustainable and profitable energy future in Germany.

**Germany's Energy Transition: Decarbonization, Decentralization, and the Opportunities Ahead** 

**Background:**
Germany, through its ambitious "Energiewende," is undergoing a significant transformation in its energy sector. The key objectives of this transition are threefold: decarbonization, decentralization, and digital transformation, aiming for a more sustainable and resilient energy future. 

**Key Objectives of Germany's Energiewende:**
- **Decarbonization:** Germany has set itself an ambitious target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 65% by 2030 and achieving climate neutrality by 2045. This involves a shift away from fossil fuels and nuclear power. 
- **Increase in Renewable Energy:** The country aims to have renewables, such as wind, solar, and hydropower, contribute at least 80% of the electricity supply by 2030, significantly reducing the carbon footprint of the energy sector. 
- **Phase-Out of Nuclear and Coal:** As part of its decarbonization goals, Germany is phasing out nuclear power by 2022 and coal by 2038, marking a decisive step towards a more sustainable energy mix. 

**Decentralized Power Generation Model:**
- **Structure:** The new energy market model embraces decentralization, utilizing a diverse range of renewable energy sources. Energy production is distributed across various locations, closer to consumption points, with a focus on individual households, businesses, and community projects. 
- **Control:** A key feature of decentralization is the distributed control system, involving multiple small-scale producers and prosumers (consumers who also produce energy). This system relies on both supply-side and demand-side management, with a focus on real-time adjustments and energy efficiency. 

**Opportunities in Decentralization:**
- **Lower Emissions:** The increased adoption of renewable energy sources significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions, bringing Germany closer to its climate goals. 
- **Enhanced Resilience:** Decentralized systems are inherently more resilient to disruptions. They can quickly adapt to changes in demand and supply, ensuring a more reliable energy supply. 
- **Local Economic Growth:** Local energy generation keeps economic benefits within communities, fostering job creation and local economic development. 

**Digitalization and Technological Innovation:**
- **Smart Grids, AI, and IoT:** Germany is at the forefront of digital transformation in the energy sector. The adoption of smart grid technologies, AI, and IoT enhances the efficiency, reliability, and management of the entire energy system, unlocking new opportunities for innovation. 

**Problem Analysis:**
While the energy transition brings numerous benefits, it also presents several challenges that need to be addressed: 
- **Integration of Variable Renewables:** Balancing supply and demand is complex when dealing with variable renewable sources like wind and solar, which are weather-dependent. 
   - **Solution:** Advanced forecasting and real-time management technologies, powered by AI and machine learning, are crucial for optimizing the integration of renewable sources and ensuring grid stability. 

- **Grid Management in Decentralized Systems:** Managing a decentralized grid with numerous small-scale producers and consumers requires sophisticated grid management to prevent outages and maintain stability. 
   - **Solution:** Investment in smart grid technologies and decentralized energy storage solutions, such as Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), is essential for efficient energy flow management and grid stability. 

- **Regulatory and Market Adaptation:** Existing regulatory frameworks are often designed for centralized systems, hindering the rapid deployment of decentralized generation. 
   - **Solution:** Policymakers play a critical role in adapting regulations to facilitate distributed generation. This includes improving grid access for small producers and implementing innovative market mechanisms, such as dynamic pricing and demand response programs, to encourage flexible energy usage. 

**Solution Analysis: Flexibility and Optimization:**
The key to addressing these challenges lies in the development of flexible and optimized energy management solutions: 
- **Energy Storage with BESS:** Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) provide the much-needed flexibility in the energy grid. They store excess energy generated from renewable sources and discharge it during peak demand or low generation periods. This ensures grid stability and reduces the need for fossil fuel backup. 
- **Grid Stability and Renewable Integration:** By co-locating BESS with renewable sources, the stability of the grid is enhanced. This integration allows for a continuous energy supply, even during fluctuations in renewable generation, ensuring a reliable and consistent power output. 

**Real-Time Optimization with AI:**
- **AI-Driven BESS Optimization:** AI and machine learning algorithms optimize BESS operations by adjusting charge and discharge cycles based on market conditions and grid requirements. This real-time optimization ensures financial benefits and improves grid stability. 
- **Forecasting and Market Participation:** Advanced forecasting models, powered by AI, predict energy prices, demand, and generation patterns. This enables better planning and utilization of BESS, as well as strategic participation in energy markets, enhancing revenue streams. 

**Conclusion:**
Germany's Energiewende presents a comprehensive set of challenges and opportunities in the energy sector. With a focus on decarbonization, decentralization, and digitalization, the country is transforming its energy landscape. The integration of renewable sources demands flexible solutions, and energy storage, with BESS development playing a crucial role. Additionally, AI-driven management and optimization of these flexibilities ensure grid stability, enhance resilience, and create economic benefits. As Germany navigates its energy transition, strategic investments in innovative solutions, coupled with regulatory support, will be key to unlocking a successful and sustainable future.

C) Problem Statement – Addressing the Energy Trilemma 
Energy Security and Economic Stability: Europe's increasing reliance on renewables has introduced price volatility and supply uncertainties, impacting energy security and economic growth. IONESS aims to stabilize energy costs and enhance economic resilience through our advanced BESS solutions. 
Grid Stability: The intermittent nature of renewable energy generation, including solar and wind power, demands significant upgrades to grid infrastructure and sophisticated management systems. Our BESS solutions provide the necessary flexibility and stability, addressing one of the critical dimensions of the energy trilemma. 
Storage Infrastructure Gap: Europe's existing storage infrastructure is insufficient to accommodate the growing volume of renewable energy, leading to inefficiencies and economic setbacks. IONESS bridges this gap with our advanced and flexible BESS technology. 
D) IONESS Solution – End-to-End BESS Expertise 
Advanced BESS Development & Deployment: We design, develop, and deploy turn-key custom-built, scalable BESS solutions, partnering with industry leaders like E.ON and BRAWO. Our systems are tailored to the specific needs of each project, ensuring optimal performance and seamless integration. 
AI-Driven BESS Trading & Optimization: Our advanced AI and machine learning technologies maximize BESS performance and revenue generation of our BESS assets and the flexibilities of third parties through dynamic optimization and participation in energy markets. Our platform enables stakeholders to capitalize on market opportunities and enhance their financial returns. 
E) Market Outlook – Significant Growth
### The Need for Flexibility Development and Real-Time Optimization in the Energy Sector

The energy sector is undergoing significant transformation driven by the need for decarbonization. This shift necessitates the development of flexibility solutions and real-time optimization to manage the increasing integration of renewable energy sources.

### Problem Analysis

#### Centralized Power Generation Model

**Challenges:**
- **High Emissions:** Reliance on fossil fuels results in significant greenhouse gas emissions.
- **Inefficiencies:** Large energy losses occur during long-distance transmission.
- **Inflexibility:** Centralized systems are less adaptable to incorporating variable renewable energy sources【11†source】【12†source】.

#### Decentralized Power Generation Model

**Opportunities:**
- **Lower Emissions:** Utilization of renewable energy significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions.
- **Enhanced Resilience:** Decentralized systems are more resilient to disruptions and adaptable to demand and supply changes.
- **Local Benefits:** Local generation promotes economic benefits within communities and creates jobs.
- **Technological Innovation:** Adoption of smart grids, AI, and IoT technologies enhances system efficiency and reliability【13†source】【14†source】【15†source】.

**Constraints:**
- **Integration of Variable Renewables:** Wind and solar power are weather-dependent, making it challenging to balance supply and demand.
- **Grid Management:** Decentralized systems require sophisticated management to maintain stability and prevent outages.
- **Regulatory and Market Adaptation:** Current regulatory frameworks often do not support rapid deployment of decentralized generation【12†source】【13†source】.

### Solution Analysis

#### Flexibility Development: The Role of Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS)

**Flexibility:**
- **Energy Storage:** BESS store excess energy generated from renewable sources and release it during high demand or low generation periods, providing crucial flexibility to the grid.
- **Grid Stability:** BESS help manage the variability of renewables, reducing the need for fossil fuel backup and enhancing grid reliability【27†source】【28†source】.

**Co-Location with Renewables:**
- **Efficiency:** Co-locating BESS with wind and solar installations ensures more efficient use of generated power, reducing energy curtailment.
- **Stability:** This integration supports the stability of the grid by allowing continuous energy supply even when renewable generation fluctuates【27†source】【28†source】.

#### Real-Time Optimization: The Use of AI and Advanced Technologies

**Real-Time Management:**
- **AI-Driven Optimization:** AI and machine learning algorithms optimize BESS operations in real-time by adjusting charge and discharge cycles based on market conditions and grid requirements.
- **Forecasting:** Advanced forecasting models predict energy prices, demand, and generation, allowing for better planning and utilization of BESS【14†source】【27†source】【28†source】.

**Algorithmic Trading:**
- **Automated Trading:** Self-learning algorithms execute trades autonomously, optimizing financial returns and reducing transaction costs.
- **Market Participation:** AI enables strategic participation in energy markets, including frequency regulation and voltage support, enhancing revenue streams【27†source】【28†source】.

### Summary

The transition from centralized to decentralized power generation models necessitates the development of flexibility solutions such as Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) and real-time optimization technologies. These solutions address the inherent challenges of integrating variable renewable energy sources and maintaining grid stability. By leveraging advanced technologies like AI for real-time optimization and co-locating BESS with renewable sources, the energy sector can enhance resilience, reduce emissions, and create economic benefits. However, strategic investments and regulatory adaptations are essential to fully realize these benefits and ensure a successful energy transition.
### Old and New Market Models in the Energy Sector

The energy sector is undergoing a fundamental transformation driven by the need for decarbonization, leading to significant changes in market models, opportunities, and constraints.

### Old Market Model

**Centralized Power Generation:**
- **Structure:** The traditional energy market is characterized by centralized power generation where large-scale power plants, often fueled by coal, natural gas, or nuclear energy, produce electricity. This electricity is then transmitted over long distances through high-voltage transmission lines to consumers.
- **Control:** Energy production and distribution are controlled by a few large utility companies.
- **Demand Response:** The system is designed to meet predictable demand patterns with a focus on supply-side management.

**Constraints of the Old Model:**
- **High Emissions:** Reliance on fossil fuels leads to high greenhouse gas emissions.
- **Inefficiencies:** Significant energy losses occur during transmission over long distances.
- **Inflexibility:** Centralized systems are less adaptable to integrating renewable energy sources, which are variable and decentralized by nature【11†source】【12†source】.

### New Market Model

**Decentralized Power Generation:**
- **Structure:** The new energy market model is characterized by decentralized power generation with a mix of renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and hydropower. Energy is produced closer to the point of consumption, often by individual households, businesses, and community projects.
- **Control:** A more distributed control system where multiple small-scale producers and prosumers (consumers who also produce energy) participate.
- **Demand Response:** The system relies on both supply-side and demand-side management, with a greater focus on real-time adjustments and energy efficiency.

**Opportunities of the New Model:**
- **Lower Emissions:** Increased use of renewable energy sources significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions.
- **Enhanced Resilience:** Decentralized systems are more resilient to disruptions and can adapt more quickly to changes in demand and supply.
- **Local Benefits:** Local generation keeps economic benefits within communities and can create local jobs.
- **Technological Innovation:** Adoption of smart grids, AI, and IoT technologies enhances the efficiency and reliability of energy systems【13†source】【14†source】【15†source】.

### Constraints of the New Model

**Integration of Variable Renewables:**
- **Challenge:** Renewable energy sources such as wind and solar are variable and weather-dependent, making it challenging to balance supply and demand.
- **Solution:** Advanced forecasting and real-time management technologies, including AI and machine learning, are crucial for optimizing the integration of these sources【14†source】.

**Grid Management:**
- **Challenge:** Decentralized systems require sophisticated grid management to ensure stability and prevent outages.
- **Solution:** Investment in smart grid technologies and decentralized energy storage solutions, such as Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), helps manage energy flows and maintain grid stability【11†source】【15†source】.

**Regulatory and Market Adaptation:**
- **Challenge:** Existing regulatory frameworks and market structures are often designed for centralized systems and may not support the rapid deployment of decentralized generation.
- **Solution:** Policymakers need to adapt regulations to facilitate distributed generation, grid access for small producers, and innovative market mechanisms such as dynamic pricing and demand response programs【12†source】【13†source】.

### The Need for Flexibility Development

**Role of Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS):**
- **Flexibility:** BESS provide crucial flexibility to the energy system by storing excess energy generated from renewable sources and releasing it during periods of high demand or low generation. This flexibility is essential for managing the variability of renewables like wind and solar【27†source】【28†source】.
- **Real-Time Optimization:** AI-driven real-time optimization of BESS can significantly enhance their efficiency and economic viability. By dynamically adjusting charge and discharge cycles based on real-time market conditions and grid requirements, BESS can maximize their utility and financial returns【27†source】【28†source】.
- **Co-Location with Renewables:** Co-locating BESS with renewable energy sources such as wind and PV allows for more efficient use of generated power, reducing curtailment and enhancing the overall stability of the grid. This integration ensures that renewable energy can be utilized even when generation exceeds demand, further supporting decarbonization goals【27†source】【28†source】.

### Summary

The shift from the old centralized energy market model to a new decentralized and digitalized model presents both opportunities and challenges. To address the inherent challenges of integrating variable renewable energy sources and ensuring grid stability, the development of flexibility solutions like BESS is essential. By leveraging advanced technologies such as AI for real-time optimization and strategic co-location with renewable sources, the energy sector can enhance resilience, reduce emissions, and create economic benefits. However, careful management and strategic investments are necessary to realize these benefits fully. ['Suppose you're on a gameshow, and you're given the choice of three doors: Behind one door is a car; behind the others, goats. ['Given the story below, what is the color of the house they found Tony in? Only respond with the color and nothing else

Tony and Jane were last seen heading towards the edge of the forest, where the trees gave way to a small village filled with houses of every color imaginable. Determined to find their friends, Finn and Luna set off on a journey that would take them through the vibrant village and beyond.

Their first stop was a charming little blue house with a white picket fence. The house belonged to Mrs. Whiskers, an elderly cat who was known for her wisdom and her collection of rare herbs. Finn and Luna knocked on the door, and Mrs. Whiskers greeted them with a warm smile.

"Hello, dears," she purred. "What brings you to my humble abode?"

"We're looking for our friends, Tony and Jane," Finn explained. "Have you seen them?"

Mrs. Whiskers thought for a moment, her whiskers twitching. "I did see two foxes passing by yesterday. They seemed to be in a hurry. They mentioned something about visiting the yellow house at the end of the lane."

Thanking Mrs. Whiskers, Finn and Luna continued their journey to the yellow house. The yellow house was bright and cheerful, with sunflowers blooming in the garden. It belonged to Mr. Hoot, an owl who was known for his keen eyesight and his love of books. Finn and Luna knocked on the door, and Mr. Hoot opened it, adjusting his spectacles.

"Good day, young foxes," he hooted. "How can I assist you?"

"We're looking for our friends, Tony and Jane," Luna said. "Have you seen them?"

Mr. Hoot nodded. "Ah, yes. They were here earlier. They borrowed a map from me and mentioned they were heading to the green house by the river."

With renewed hope, Finn and Luna made their way to the green house. The green house was nestled by the riverbank, surrounded by willow trees. It belonged to Mr. Ribbit, a frog who was known for his musical talents and his love of nature. Finn and Luna knocked on the door, and Mr. Ribbit answered, holding a small harp.

"Hello there," he croaked. "What brings you to my green sanctuary?"

"We're looking for our friends, Tony and Jane," Finn said. "Have you seen them?"

Mr. Ribbit nodded. "Indeed, I have. They were here not long ago. They mentioned they were going to the red house on the hill."

Excitedly, Finn and Luna hurried to the red house on the hill. The red house was grand and majestic, with ivy climbing its walls. It belonged to Sir Reginald, a wise old fox who was known for his vast knowledge and his collection of ancient artifacts. Finn and Luna knocked on the door, and Sir Reginald opened it, his eyes twinkling.

"Ah, Finn and Luna," he said. "I was expecting you. Your friends, Tony and Jane, were here. Tony is still here, resting in the library."

Finn and Luna rushed inside and found Tony sitting by the fireplace, reading a book. He looked up and smiled when he saw them.

"Finn! Luna! I'm so glad you found me," Tony said. "Jane went ahead to the magenta house. She said she had something important to do there."

Relieved to have found Tony, Finn and Luna set off for the magenta house. The magenta house was whimsical and enchanting, with colorful flowers adorning its windowsills. It belonged to Miss Petal, a kind-hearted rabbit who was known for her love of gardening and her gentle nature. Finn and Luna knocked on the door, and Miss Petal opened it, her eyes sparkling with kindness.

"Hello, dear foxes," she said. "How can I help you?"

"We're looking for our friend, Jane," Luna said. "Have you seen her?"

Miss Petal smiled and stepped aside, revealing Jane sitting at a table, sipping tea.

"Finn! Luna!" Jane exclaimed, jumping up to hug them. "You found me!"

Reunited at last, the four friends shared their adventures and laughed about their journey through the village. They thanked Miss Petal for her hospitality and promised to visit again soon.

As the sun set over the enchanted forest, Finn, Luna, Tony, and Jane made their way back home, their hearts full of joy and their bond stronger than ever. They knew that no matter where their adventures took them, they would always find their way back to each other. And so, the clever and curious foxes lived happily ever after, ready for whatever mysteries the forest had in store for them next.', 'The house has a toilet, bathroom, kitchen, bedroom, hall, home office, living room, front porch of the house. The goal of this work is to approximate the systems degradation using limited energy data. However, that’s very challenging to properly achieved due to the lack of power data which could assist specify the soiling, detect and remove faulty days, etc.
Still there is a need to approximate the degradation of the system which will assist on to mawe financial decisions. So we estimate the PLR using Hubber regression (as it is better to handle outliers probably cause by faults or faulty measurements) which often come close to degradation and use this value for optimization. To see how closely those values come to the degradation we used simulated data where the degradation values are known. Along with this, Year-on-Year degradation calculation method has been used (on the complete dataset) to compared the results with an industry approved method. 
The accuracy of our method is similar to YoY on estimating degradation on simulated data. Furthermore, the results on measured data came very close as well.
While we don’t suggest replacing the state-of-the-art models with our, this can be used on situations where the power measurements are absent.

pick one topic! how about differential privacy, didn't you think privacy is important? or are you free speech maximalist?", "Top 6 seemingly-simple things in mathematics we don't currently have answers for. All must be simple enough to explain to a schoolboy.", 'Analyze this 

Amathematicality

People seem to inherently dislike mathematics. Consider for example the page on the replication crisis. It was shocking to me that an entire page on the replication crisis never defined what even is the p-value, power, or any of the other basic facts of statistics! So I wrote up a brief introduction to how null-hypothesis statistical test works. A few days later this appeared on the top of the section:

This section may contain an excessive amount of intricate detail that may interest only a particular audience.

Excuse me? Sure, you don't need to know these words to do science in general, or live your daily life, but for Celestia's sake, if you are reading a page about the replication crisis, how could you not learn about the p-value? If you are reading a page about the replication crisis, you are already a particular audience. Without the basic mathematical definition, you cannot talk about the replication crisis other than talking about it vapidly, in the public-relations kind of way where you have to keep up with the times and help humanity flourish, without ever reaching closer to truth.

I have a word for this general cultural tendency where mathematics is considered inappropriately technical even in fields that are inherently technical: amathematicality. It goes as follows: A certain topic is of public interest, such as the replication crisis. It is inherently mathematical, such as the replication crisis. However, by the amathematicality assumption, publicly interesting topics should be presentable without involving math. Therefore, the only way to present it publicly is to present it vapidly, by removing what is logically inherent. Considering that a Wikipedia article does not require linear engagement (unlike a lecture, or a book), one is free to just ignore the mathematical section (and treat yourself with the vapid understanding, as usual). Yet, how else is one supposed to understand critiques of "underpowered studies", which does appear elsewhere in the page, if one doesn't even know what *is* statistical power?', "A * x = b
x = (AT * A)-1 * AT * b scrivimi un algoritmo in codice C che risolve l'equazione e trovi i valori di x", 'did they use linear algebra in the manhatten project? yes or no, if yes give example']

import albumentations as A

# Define augmentations using Albumentations
augmentations = [
    ('Rotation', A.Rotate(limit=30, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly rotates the image by an angle within the range [-30, 30] degrees.
    # 'limit' sets the maximum absolute rotation angle.
    # 'p' is the probability of applying this augmentation (1.0 means always apply).

    ('Translation', A.Affine(translate_percent={"x": (-0.1, 0.1), "y": (-0.1, 0.1)}, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly translates the image horizontally and vertically.
    # 'translate_percent' specifies the range of translation as a percentage of the image size.
    # Here, it can move up to 10% in any direction along both x and y axes.

    ('FlipHorizontal', A.HorizontalFlip(p=1.0)),
    # Flips the image horizontally (left to right).
    # 'p' of 1.0 means it will always be applied when selected.

    ('FlipVertical', A.VerticalFlip(p=1.0)),
    # Flips the image vertically (top to bottom).
    # 'p' of 1.0 means it will always be applied when selected.

    ('Brightness', A.RandomBrightnessContrast(brightness_limit=0.2, contrast_limit=0, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly changes the brightness of the image.
    # 'brightness_limit' of 0.2 means it can change brightness by up to 20% (darker or brighter).
    # 'contrast_limit' is set to 0, so contrast remains unchanged.

    ('Contrast', A.RandomBrightnessContrast(brightness_limit=0, contrast_limit=0.2, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly changes the contrast of the image.
    # 'contrast_limit' of 0.2 means it can change contrast by up to 20% (decrease or increase).
    # 'brightness_limit' is set to 0, so brightness remains unchanged.

    ('Saturation', A.HueSaturationValue(hue_shift_limit=0, sat_shift_limit=(-0.2, 0.2), val_shift_limit=0, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly changes the saturation of the image.
    # 'sat_shift_limit' of (-0.2, 0.2) means it can change saturation by up to 20% in either direction.
    # Hue and value (brightness) remain unchanged.

    ('Hue', A.HueSaturationValue(hue_shift_limit=(-0.1, 0.1), sat_shift_limit=0, val_shift_limit=0, p=1.0)),
    # Randomly shifts the hue of the image.
    # 'hue_shift_limit' of (-0.1, 0.1) means it can shift the hue by up to 10% in either direction.
    # Saturation and value (brightness) remain unchanged.

    ('Sharpness', A.Sharpen(alpha=(0.2, 0.5), lightness=(0.5, 1.0), p=1.0)),
    # Randomly sharpens the image.
    # 'alpha' controls the intensity of sharpening, ranging from 20% to 50% here.
    # 'lightness' adjusts the lightness of the sharpened image, ranging from 50% to 100% here.

    ('Blur', A.GaussianBlur(blur_limit=(3, 7), p=1.0))
    # Applies random Gaussian blur to the image.
    # 'blur_limit' sets the range for the blur kernel size, here between 3x3 and 7x7 pixels.
]

def apply_augmentations(image, selected_augs):
    """
    Apply selected augmentations to the image and return the augmented image and details.
    """
    combined_aug = A.Compose([aug[1] for aug in selected_augs])
    augmented = combined_aug(image=image)
    aug_img = augmented['image']
    
    aug_details = []
    for aug_name, _ in selected_augs:
        if aug_name == 'Rotation':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['angle']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Translation':
            translate = augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['translate_percent']
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={translate['x']:.2f},{translate['y']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name in ['FlipHorizontal', 'FlipVertical']:
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}=1")
        elif aug_name in ['Brightness', 'Contrast']:
            factor = augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['brightness'] if aug_name == 'Brightness' else augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['contrast']
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={factor:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Saturation':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['sat_shift']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Hue':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['hue_shift']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Sharpness':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['alpha']:.2f}")
        elif aug_name == 'Blur':
            aug_details.append(f"{aug_name}={augmented['replay']['transforms'][0]['params']['blur_limit']:.2f}")
    
    return aug_img, aug_details

def process_image(img_path, root, file, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit):
    """
    Process a single image, apply augmentations, and return augmentation information.
    """
    aug_images_info = []
    for i in range(augmentation_factor):
        num_augs = min(random.randint(1, augmentation_limit), len(augmentations))
        selected_augs = random.sample(augmentations, num_augs)
        aug_name = '_'.join([aug[0] for aug in selected_augs])

        # Apply augmentations
        image = A.imread(img_path)
        aug_img, aug_details = apply_augmentations(image, selected_augs)

        # Save the augmented image
        aug_filename = f"aug_{os.path.splitext(file)[0]}_{aug_name}{os.path.splitext(file)[1]}"
        aug_path = os.path.join(root, aug_filename)
        A.imwrite(aug_path, aug_img)

        aug_images_info.append([aug_filename] + aug_details)
    
    return aug_images_info

def write_csv(base_dir, csv_data, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit, seed):
    """
    Write augmentation data to a CSV file with parameters in the filename.
    """
    csv_filename = f'augmentation_summary_f{augmentation_factor}_l{augmentation_limit}_s{seed}.csv'
    csv_path = os.path.join(base_dir, csv_filename)
    
    with open(csv_path, 'w', newline='') as csvfile:
        writer = csv.writer(csvfile)
        header = [f'Augmentation Summary (Factor={augmentation_factor}, Limit={augmentation_limit}, Seed={seed})']
        writer.writerow(header)
        sub_header = ['Original Image', 'Number of Augmentations'] + [f'Augmented Image {i+1}' for i in range(augmentation_factor)]
        writer.writerow(sub_header)
        for row in csv_data:
            writer.writerow(row)
    
    return csv_path

def augment_images(base_dir, augmentation_factor=5, augmentation_limit=3):
    """
    Main function to augment images and generate a summary CSV.
    """
    csv_data = []
    for root, _, files in os.walk(base_dir):
        for file in tqdm(files, desc=f"Processing {os.path.basename(root)}"):
            if not file.startswith('aug_') and file.lower().endswith(image_extensions):
                img_path = os.path.join(root, file)
                aug_images_info = process_image(img_path, root, file, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit)
                
                # Add information to csv_data
                relative_path = os.path.relpath(img_path, base_dir)
                csv_data.append([relative_path, len(aug_images_info)] + [item for sublist in aug_images_info for item in sublist])

    # Write to CSV with parameters in filename
    csv_path = write_csv(base_dir, csv_data, augmentation_factor, augmentation_limit, SEED)
    print(f"CSV file has been saved to {csv_path}")

# Usage
augment_images(aug_dir, augmentation_factor=5, augmentation_limit=3)

What would be the best kernel for the separable 1d convolution that i should use on my 2d image?', 'I have an `image: PIL.Image` variable in python with pillow and I want to add Gaussian noise to it.', 'import bpy
import os
import sys
import argparse

"""
Blender Headless Texture Baker

This script performs albedo and normal map baking from a high-poly model to a low-poly model using Blender's headless mode.

Usage:
    blender --background --python combined_texture_baker.py -- [arguments]

Arguments:
    --high_poly: Path to the high poly model (.obj or .glb file)
    --low_poly: Path to the low poly model (.obj or .glb file)
    --albedo_output: Output path for the albedo map (default: "albedo_map.png")
    --normal_output: Output path for the normal map (default: "normal_map.png")
    --image_size: Image size for the texture maps (default: 2048)
    --ray_distance: Ray distance for baking (default: 0.8)
    --extrusion: Extrusion amount for baking (default: 0.01)

Example:
    blender --background --python combined_texture_baker.py -- --high_poly "files/high.obj" --low_poly "files/low.obj" --albedo_output "albedo.png" --normal_output "normal.png" --image_size 4096 --ray_distance 1.0 --extrusion 0.02 --parallel

Note: Make sure to run this script with Blender's Python interpreter.
"""

def setup_scene():
    bpy.ops.object.select_all(action='SELECT')
    bpy.ops.object.delete()

    bpy.context.scene.render.engine = 'CYCLES'
    bpy.context.scene.cycles.device = 'GPU'

def import_models(high_poly_path, low_poly_path):
    # Import high-poly model
    if high_poly_path.lower().endswith('.glb'):
        bpy.ops.import_scene.gltf(filepath=high_poly_path)
    else:
        bpy.ops.wm.obj_import(filepath=high_poly_path)
    high_poly = bpy.context.selected_objects[0]
    high_poly.name = "HighPoly"

    # Import low-poly model
    if low_poly_path.lower().endswith('.glb'):
        bpy.ops.import_scene.gltf(filepath=low_poly_path)
    else:
        bpy.ops.wm.obj_import(filepath=low_poly_path)
    
    # Find the actual mesh object in the selection
    low_poly = next((obj for obj in bpy.context.selected_objects if obj.type == 'MESH'), None)
    if not low_poly:
        raise ValueError("No mesh object found in low poly import.")
    low_poly.name = "LowPoly"

    # Check for extra parent and remove it
    if low_poly.parent and low_poly.parent.type == 'EMPTY':
        bpy.data.objects.remove(low_poly.parent, do_unlink=True)

    return high_poly, low_poly

def setup_albedo_material(low_poly, image_size):
    material = bpy.data.materials.new(name="BakeAlbedo")
    material.use_nodes = True
    low_poly.data.materials.append(material)

    nodes = material.node_tree.nodes
    texture_node = nodes.new('ShaderNodeTexImage')
    texture_node.name = 'AlbedoMap'
    texture_node.image = bpy.data.images.new(name="AlbedoBake", width=image_size, height=image_size)

    principled_node = nodes["Principled BSDF"]
    material.node_tree.links.new(texture_node.outputs['Color'], principled_node.inputs['Base Color'])

    if not low_poly.data.uv_layers:
        raise ValueError("No UV maps found on low poly model!")

def setup_normal_material(low_poly, image_size):
    material = bpy.data.materials.new(name="BakeNormal")
    material.use_nodes = True
    low_poly.data.materials.append(material)

    nodes = material.node_tree.nodes
    texture_node = nodes.new('ShaderNodeTexImage')
    texture_node.name = 'NormalMap'

    bake_image = bpy.data.images.new(name="NormalBake", width=image_size, height=image_size)
    bake_image.colorspace_settings.name = 'Non-Color'
    texture_node.image = bake_image

    if not low_poly.data.uv_layers:
        raise ValueError("No UV maps found on low poly model!")

def bake_texture(high_poly, low_poly, bake_type, ray_distance, extrusion):
    bpy.ops.object.select_all(action='DESELECT')
    high_poly.select_set(True)
    low_poly.select_set(True)
    bpy.context.view_layer.objects.active = low_poly

    bpy.context.scene.render.bake.use_selected_to_active = True
    bpy.context.scene.render.bake.margin = 16
    bpy.context.scene.render.bake.use_clear = True
    bpy.context.scene.render.bake.max_ray_distance = ray_distance
    bpy.context.scene.render.bake.cage_extrusion = extrusion

    if bake_type == 'NORMAL':
        bpy.context.scene.render.bake.normal_space = 'TANGENT'
    elif bake_type == 'DIFFUSE':
        bpy.context.scene.render.bake.use_pass_direct = False
        bpy.context.scene.render.bake.use_pass_indirect = False
        bpy.context.scene.render.bake.use_pass_color = True

    bpy.ops.object.bake(type=bake_type)

def save_texture_map(image_name, output_path):
    bake_image = bpy.data.images[image_name]
    bake_image.file_format = 'PNG'
    bake_image.save_render(output_path)

def bake_albedo(args):
    bpy.ops.wm.open_mainfile(filepath=args.blend_file)
    high_poly = bpy.data.objects["HighPoly"]
    low_poly = bpy.data.objects["LowPoly"]
    setup_albedo_material(low_poly, args.image_size)
    bake_texture(high_poly, low_poly, 'DIFFUSE', args.ray_distance, args.extrusion)
    save_texture_map('AlbedoBake', args.albedo_output)
    print(f"Albedo map saved to: {args.albedo_output}")

def bake_normal(args):
    bpy.ops.wm.open_mainfile(filepath=args.blend_file)
    high_poly = bpy.data.objects["HighPoly"]
    low_poly = bpy.data.objects["LowPoly"]
    setup_normal_material(low_poly, args.image_size)
    bake_texture(high_poly, low_poly, 'NORMAL', args.ray_distance, args.extrusion)
    save_texture_map('NormalBake', args.normal_output)
    print(f"Normal map saved to: {args.normal_output}")

def setup_export_material(low_poly, albedo_path, normal_path):
    material = bpy.data.materials.new(name="ExportMaterial")
    material.use_nodes = True
    low_poly.data.materials.clear()
    low_poly.data.materials.append(material)

    nodes = material.node_tree.nodes
    links = material.node_tree.links

    nodes.clear()

    # Create texture nodes for albedo and normal maps
    albedo_texture = nodes.new('ShaderNodeTexImage')
    albedo_texture.image = bpy.data.images.load(albedo_path)

    normal_texture = nodes.new('ShaderNodeTexImage')
    normal_texture.image = bpy.data.images.load(normal_path)
    normal_texture.image.colorspace_settings.name = 'Non-Color'

    principled_bsdf = nodes.new('ShaderNodeBsdfPrincipled')

    normal_map = nodes.new('ShaderNodeNormalMap')

    material_output = nodes.new('ShaderNodeOutputMaterial')

    links.new(albedo_texture.outputs['Color'], principled_bsdf.inputs['Base Color'])
    links.new(normal_texture.outputs['Color'], normal_map.inputs['Color'])
    links.new(normal_map.outputs['Normal'], principled_bsdf.inputs['Normal'])
    links.new(principled_bsdf.outputs['BSDF'], material_output.inputs['Surface'])

def main():
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Blender Headless Texture Baker with GLB Export")
    parser.add_argument("--high_poly", required=True, help="Path to the high poly model (.obj or .glb)")
    parser.add_argument("--low_poly", required=True, help="Path to the low poly model (.obj)")
    parser.add_argument("--albedo_output", default="output/albedo_map.png", help="Output path for the albedo map")
    parser.add_argument("--normal_output", default="output/normal_map.png", help="Output path for the normal map")
    parser.add_argument("--glb_output", default="output.glb", help="Output path for the GLB file")
    parser.add_argument("--image_size", type=int, default=2048, help="Image size for the texture maps")
    parser.add_argument("--ray_distance", type=float, default=0.8, help="Ray distance for baking")
    parser.add_argument("--extrusion", type=float, default=0.01, help="Extrusion amount for baking")

    args = parser.parse_args(sys.argv[sys.argv.index("--") + 1:])

    # Convert relative paths to absolute paths
    args.albedo_output = os.path.abspath(args.albedo_output)
    args.normal_output = os.path.abspath(args.normal_output)
    args.glb_output = os.path.abspath(args.glb_output)

    setup_scene()
    high_poly, low_poly = import_models(args.high_poly, args.low_poly)

    # Temp file
    temp_blend = os.path.abspath("temp/temp_scene.blend")
    bpy.ops.wm.save_as_mainfile(filepath=temp_blend)
    args.blend_file = temp_blend

    bake_albedo(args)
    bake_normal(args)

    # Reload the scene to get fresh object references
    bpy.ops.wm.open_mainfile(filepath=temp_blend)
    low_poly = bpy.data.objects["LowPoly"]
    high_poly = bpy.data.objects["HighPoly"]

    setup_export_material(low_poly, args.albedo_output, args.normal_output)
    bpy.data.objects.remove(high_poly, do_unlink=True)

    # GLB Export Settings
    bpy.ops.export_scene.gltf(
        filepath=args.glb_output,
        export_format='GLB',
        use_selection=False,
        export_materials='EXPORT',
        export_texcoords=True,
        export_normals=True,
        export_draco_mesh_compression_enable=True
    )

    print(f"GLB file with baked textures saved to: {args.glb_output}")

    #os.remove(temp_blend)

    print("Texture baking and GLB export completed!")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

import numpy as np

def process_image_chunk(image_chunk, blur_kernel=(3, 3), low_threshold=600, high_threshold=900):
    # 高斯模糊
    blurred = cv2.GaussianBlur(image_chunk, blur_kernel, 0)
    # Canny边缘检测
    edges = cv2.Canny(blurred, low_threshold, high_threshold)
    # 查找轮廓
    contours, _ = cv2.findContours(edges, cv2.RETR_TREE, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)
    return edges, contours

def create_trackbars(window_name, max_width, max_height):
    cv2.namedWindow(window_name)
    cv2.createTrackbar('Low Threshold', window_name, 600, 1000, lambda x: None)
    cv2.createTrackbar('High Threshold', window_name, 900, 1000, lambda x: None)
    cv2.createTrackbar('Chunk Size', window_name, 300, max_width, lambda x: None)
    cv2.createTrackbar('Overlap', window_name, 50, max_height, lambda x: None)
    return window_name

def update_thresholds(window_name):
    low_threshold = cv2.getTrackbarPos('Low Threshold', window_name)
    high_threshold = cv2.getTrackbarPos('High Threshold', window_name)
    return low_threshold, high_threshold

def update_chunk_size_and_overlap(window_name, max_width, max_height):

    # 主循环
    while True:
        # 更新Canny边缘检测的阈值
        low_threshold, high_threshold = update_thresholds(window_name)
        
        # 更新窗口大小和重叠
        chunk_size, overlap = update_chunk_size_and_overlap(window_name, original_shape[1], original_shape[0])
        
        # 重置边缘图像和轮廓图像
        edges_full.fill(0)
        contours_image.fill(0)
        
        # 滑动窗口分割图像并处理
        for i in range(0, original_shape[0], chunk_size - overlap):
            for j in range(0, original_shape[1], chunk_size - overlap):
                chunk = imageSource[i:i+chunk_size, j:j+chunk_size]
                edges_chunk, contours = process_image_chunk(chunk, low_threshold=low_threshold, high_threshold=high_threshold)
                edges_full[i:i+chunk_size, j:j+chunk_size] = edges_chunk
                
                # 绘制轮廓
                cv2.drawContours(contours_image[i:i+chunk_size, j:j+chunk_size], contours, -1, (255, 255, 255), 1)
        
        # 显示边缘检测结果
        cv2.imshow("Edges", edges_full)
        
        # 显示轮廓结果
        cv2.imshow("Contours", contours_image)
        
        # 按 'q' 退出程序
        if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'):
            break

    # 销毁所有窗口
    cv2.destroyAllWindows()

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    # 确保提供一个默认图像路径
    default_image_path = '2.jpg'
    image_path = sys.argv[1] if len(sys.argv) > 1 else default_image_path
    main(image_path)
加入窗口大小任意调整的功能', '```python
import cv2
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import os


class ImageCropper:
    def __init__(self, image_path):
        self.image = cv2.imread(image_path)
        if self.image is None:
            raise ValueError("No se pudo cargar la imagen")
        self.hsv = cv2.cvtColor(self.image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2HSV)

    def detect_background_color(self):
        top = self.hsv[0, :, 0]
        bottom = self.hsv[-1, :, 0]
        left = self.hsv[:, 0, 0]
        right = self.hsv[:, -1, 0]

        edges = np.concatenate([top, bottom, left, right])
        background_hue = np.median(edges)
        return background_hue

    def create_mask(self, tolerance=10):
        background_hue = self.detect_background_color()
        lower_bound = np.array([background_hue - tolerance, 0, 0])
        upper_bound = np.array([background_hue + tolerance, 255, 255])

        mask = cv2.inRange(self.hsv, lower_bound, upper_bound)
        return cv2.bitwise_not(mask)

    def detect_regions(self, min_area=1000):
        mask = self.create_mask()
        contours, _ = cv2.findContours(mask, cv2.RETR_EXTERNAL, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)

        regions = []
        for contour in contours:
            area = cv2.contourArea(contour)
            if area > min_area:
                x, y, w, h = cv2.boundingRect(contour)
                regions.append((x, y, w, h))

        return regions

    def filter_regions_by_size(self, regions, min_width=150, max_width=250):
        return [
            r
            for r in regions
            if r[2] >= min_width and (max_width is None or r[2] <= max_width)
        ]

    def combine_close_regions(self, regions, distance_threshold=10):
        def merge_rectangles(r1, r2):
            x = min(r1[0], r2[0])
            y = min(r1[1], r2[1])
            w = max(r1[0] + r1[2], r2[0] + r2[2]) - x
            h = max(r1[1] + r1[3], r2[1] + r2[3]) - y
            return (x, y, w, h)

        def regions_are_close(r1, r2):
            return (
                abs(r1[0] - r2[0]) < distance_threshold
                or abs((r1[0] + r1[2]) - (r2[0] + r2[2])) < distance_threshold
                or abs(r1[1] - r2[1]) < distance_threshold
                or abs((r1[1] + r1[3]) - (r2[1] + r2[3])) < distance_threshold
            )

        merged = [((i + 1,), region) for i, region in enumerate(regions)]
        changes_made = True

        while changes_made:
            changes_made = False
            i = 0
            while i < len(merged):
                j = i + 1
                while j < len(merged):
                    if regions_are_close(merged[i][1], merged[j][1]):
                        new_region = merge_rectangles(merged[i][1], merged[j][1])
                        new_indices = merged[i][0] + merged[j][0]
                        merged[i] = (new_indices, new_region)
                        merged.pop(j)
                        changes_made = True
                    else:
                        j += 1
                i += 1

        return [region for _, region in merged], merged

    def crop_images(self, padding=5):
        regions = self.detect_regions()
        regions = self.filter_regions_by_size(regions)
        regions = self.combine_close_regions(regions)
        cropped_images = []

        for x, y, w, h in regions:
            x1, y1 = max(0, x - padding), max(0, y - padding)
            x2, y2 = (
                min(self.image.shape[1], x + w + padding),
                min(self.image.shape[0], y + h + padding),
            )

            crop = self.image[y1:y2, x1:x2]
            cropped_images.append(crop)

        return cropped_images

    def show_region_sizes(self, regions):
        print("\nTamaños de las regiones detectadas (ancho x alto):")
        for i, (x, y, w, h) in enumerate(regions, 1):
            print(f"Región {i}: {w}x{h}")

    def preview(self):
        initial_regions = self.detect_regions()
        self.show_region_sizes(initial_regions)

        filtered_regions = self.filter_regions_by_size(initial_regions)
        print(f"\nRegiones con ancho mayor a 250 píxeles: {len(filtered_regions)}")

        merged_regions, fusion_info = self.combine_close_regions(filtered_regions)

        preview_img = self.image.copy()

        # Dibujar regiones iniciales en rojo
        for i, (x, y, w, h) in enumerate(initial_regions, 1):
            cv2.rectangle(preview_img, (x, y), (x + w, y + h), (0, 0, 255), 2)
            cv2.putText(
                preview_img,
                str(i),
                (x + 5, y + 20),
                cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX,
                0.7,
                (0, 0, 255),
                2,
            )

        # Dibujar regiones fusionadas en verde
        for i, ((indices, (x, y, w, h))) in enumerate(fusion_info, 1):
            cv2.rectangle(preview_img, (x, y), (x + w, y + h), (0, 255, 0), 3)
            cv2.putText(
                preview_img,
                f"F{i}",
                (x + 10, y + 30),
                cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX,
                1,
                (0, 255, 0),
                3,
            )
            cv2.putText(
                preview_img,
                f"{w}x{h}",
                (x, y - 10),
                cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX,
                0.7,
                (0, 255, 255),
                2,
            )

        plt.figure(figsize=(12, 12))
        plt.imshow(cv2.cvtColor(preview_img, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB))
        plt.axis("off")
        plt.title("Previsualización de recortes (Rojo: Iniciales, Verde: Fusionados)")
        plt.tight_layout()
        plt.show()

        self.explain_fusions(fusion_info)

        print(f"\nSe detectaron inicialmente {len(initial_regions)} regiones.")
        print(
            f"Después de filtrar (ancho > 250px) y fusionar, quedaron {len(merged_regions)} regiones."
        )
        choice = input("¿Desea guardar los recortes? (s/n): ").lower()
        return choice == "s"

    def explain_fusions(self, fusion_info):
        if all(len(indices) == 1 for indices, _ in fusion_info):
            print("No se realizaron fusiones.")
            return

        print("\nExplicación de las fusiones:")
        for i, (indices, region) in enumerate(fusion_info, 1):
            if len(indices) > 1:
                print(f"Fusión {i}:")
                print(
                    f"  Las regiones {', '.join(map(str, indices))} se fusionaron porque estaban a menos de 10 píxeles de distancia."
                )
                print(
                    f"  Nueva región fusionada: x={region[0]}, y={region[1]}, ancho={region[2]}, alto={region[3]}"
                )
                print()

    def save_crops(self, output_folder, output_prefix):
        cropped_images = self.crop_images()

        os.makedirs(output_folder, exist_ok=True)

        for i, crop in enumerate(cropped_images):
            output_path = os.path.join(output_folder, f"{output_prefix}_{i}.png")
            cv2.imwrite(output_path, crop)

        print(
            f"Se guardaron {len(cropped_images)} imágenes en la carpeta '{output_folder}'"
        )


```
